The combination of low pH, high PaCO2, and high HCO3- is characteristic of acute-on-chronic respiratory acidosis. The elevated bicarbonate level indicates a chronic compensatory response to the underlying respiratory acidosis (due to COPD), while the low pH suggests an acute exacerbation of the condition, leading to a superimposed acute respiratory acidosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute respiratory acidosis: While the patient has an acute component, the elevated bicarbonate suggests a chronic underlying process as well.

 

Option B. Metabolic alkalosis: This would be characterized by a high pH and high bicarbonate level, which is not seen in this case.

 

Option D. Chronic respiratory acidosis: While the patient does have chronic respiratory acidosis, the acute exacerbation indicated by the low pH makes this answer incomplete.

 

Educational objective:

 

The ABG picture above is of acute on chronic respiratory acidosis.

choices.text: Uterine artery - Ovarian artery - Internal iliac artery
Uterine artery - Ovarian artery - Vaginal artery
Uterine artery - Ovarian artery - External iliac artery
Uterine artery - Pudendal artery - Vaginal artery

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman experiences severe postpartum hemorrhage following a vaginal delivery. Despite initial management, the bleeding persists, and she is taken to the operating room for surgical intervention. The obstetrician decides to ligate the blood vessels supplying the uterus to control the hemorrhage. What is the correct sequence of blood vessel ligation?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Uterine artery - Ovarian artery - Internal iliac artery

 

  • The management of severe postpartum hemorrhage often involves surgical intervention when medical management fails.
  • The ligation of blood vessels supplying the uterus is a critical step. The correct sequence starts with:
  1. Uterine artery: This artery is the main blood supply to the uterus, and its ligation is the first step to reduce blood flow and control bleeding.
  2. Ovarian artery: If bleeding continues after ligation of the uterine artery, the ovarian artery, which also contributes to the blood supply of the uterus, is ligated next.
  3. Internal iliac artery: As a final measure, the internal iliac artery may be ligated to further reduce pelvic blood flow and control severe hemorrhage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Uterine artery - Ovarian artery - Vaginal artery: While the vaginal artery does supply blood to the vaginal area, its contribution to uterine blood flow is less significant compared to the uterine and ovarian arteries. Thus, it is not part of the primary sequence for controlling severe uterine hemorrhage.

 

Option C. Uterine artery - Ovarian artery - External iliac artery: The external iliac artery supplies blood to the lower limbs and is not directly involved in the blood supply to the uterus. Ligation of this artery would not be effective in managing postpartum hemorrhage.

 

Option D. Uterine artery - Pudendal artery - Vaginal artery: The pudendal artery primarily supplies the perineum and external genitalia, not the uterus. Ligation of the pudendal artery would not be effective in controlling uterine hemorrhage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In cases of severe postpartum hemorrhage, the correct sequence of blood vessel ligation to control bleeding involves starting with the uterine artery, followed by the ovarian artery, and finally the internal iliac artery if necessary.

choices.text: Standard error of the mean

questions.text: Researchers conducted a study to evaluate the nutritional status among young children in both rural and urban settings. They identified 30 malnourished children in rural areas and 20 in urban areas from their sample. Which statistical test is most appropriate to determine if there is a significant difference in the prevalence of malnutrition between these two geographical locations?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Chi Square test

 

  • The Chi Square test is ideal for this scenario as it is used to determine whether there is a statistically significant association between two categorical variables. Here, the two variables are 'nutritional status' (malnourished or not malnourished) and 'location' (rural or urban).
  • This test will assess if there is a significant difference in the incidence of malnutrition between the two groups.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Paired T test: This test is inappropriate here as it is used for comparing means of two related samples (e.g., before and after measurements on the same subjects), which is not the case here.

 

Option C. Standard error of the mean: This is a measure of how much estimate of the mean varies from sample to sample, not suitable for testing differences between groups in this context.

 

Option D. ANOVA: Used to compare the means across three or more groups, which does not apply to this binary categorical comparison of malnourished status by location.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Samter triad – Asthma, Nasal polyposis (ethmoidal), bronchiectasis
Kartagener syndrome – Recurrent sinusitis, asthma, infertility due to azoospermia
Young syndrome – Asthma, bronchiectasis, infertility due to hormonal imbalance
Gradenigo’s triad – Retro-orbital pain, diplopia, ear discharge

questions.text: Find the correct option among the following:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Gradenigo’s triad – Retro-orbital pain, diplopia, ear discharge

 

  • Gradenigo’s triad is characterized by retro-orbital pain, diplopia due to involvement of the sixth cranial nerve (abducens nerve palsy), and ear discharge due to otitis media.
  • This triad results from the spread of infection from the middle ear to the petrous apex of the temporal bone, causing petrous apicitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Samter triad: Incorrect. Samter triad includes asthma, nasal polyposis, and aspirin sensitivity, not bronchiectasis.

 

Option B. Kartagener syndrome: Incorrect. Kartagener syndrome involves recurrent sinusitis, bronchiectasis, and infertility due to defective ciliary function (not pleural effusion).

 

Option C. Young syndrome: Incorrect. Young syndrome is characterized by recurrent sinusitis, bronchiectasis, and infertility due to obstructive azoospermia, not hormonal imbalance.

 

Educational Objective:

Gradenigo’s triad consists of retro-orbital pain, diplopia, and ear discharge. It is a rare complication of otitis media involving the petrous apex of the temporal bone

questions.text: A biochemist is developing monoclonal antibodies using the hybridoma technique, so which biochemical pathway is exploited to ensure the survival of hybrid cells?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Purine salvage pathway

 

  • The hybridoma technique relies on the purine salvage pathway to produce monoclonal antibodies.
  • During the hybridoma process, myeloma cells that cannot synthesize purines de novo are fused with spleen cells from immunized mice.
  • The hybrid cells can survive and proliferate because they utilize the purine salvage pathway, which allows them to bypass the block in purine synthesis.
  • This selective survival ensures that only the hybrid cells, which produce the desired monoclonal antibodies, are maintained.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Krebs cycle: This pathway is involved in cellular respiration and energy production but is not specifically exploited in the hybridoma technique for monoclonal antibody production.

 

Option B. Pentose Phosphate pathway: This pathway is involved in the generation of NADPH and ribose-5-phosphate but is not directly related to the survival of hybridoma cells in the context of monoclonal antibody production.

 

Option D. Glycolytic pathway: While essential for cellular metabolism and energy production, the glycolytic pathway is not the specific pathway utilized in the hybridoma technique to ensure the survival of hybrid cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The purine salvage pathway is crucial in the hybridoma technique for the production of monoclonal antibodies, allowing hybrid cells to survive and proliferate by bypassing blocks in purine synthesis.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman undergoing chemotherapy for breast cancer presents with a significant decrease in platelet count after her last treatment cycle. Which of the following agents is most appropriate to manage her thrombocytopenia?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Oprelvekin (IL-11)

 

  • Oprelvekin, an interleukin-11 analog, is specifically used to stimulate platelet production and is indicated in patients experiencing thrombocytopenia following chemotherapy.
  • It works by promoting the proliferation of megakaryocyte progenitors, which are precursor cells in platelet formation, thereby increasing platelet counts and reducing the risk of bleeding associated with low platelet levels.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Filgrastim: This is a granulocyte-colony stimulating factor (G-CSF) used to treat neutropenia by stimulating the bone marrow to produce more neutrophils, not platelets.

 

Option C. Erythropoietin: Mainly used to treat anemia, especially in chronic kidney disease or anemia caused by chemotherapy, as it stimulates red blood cell production.

 

Option D. Amifostine: Used primarily to reduce the risk of renal toxicity in patients receiving cisplatin-based chemotherapy and not for addressing thrombocytopenia.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • Oprelvekin (IL-11) is effectively used to increase platelet counts in patients with chemotherapy-induced thrombocytopenia, thereby helping to manage bleeding risks associated with low platelet levels.

questions.text: A patient undergoing chemotherapy treatment reports symptoms of hand-foot syndrome, characterized by redness, swelling, and pain on the palms of the hands and the soles of the feet. Which anticancer drug is most likely responsible for this adverse effect?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Capecitabine

 

  • Hand-foot syndrome is notably associated with Capecitabine, an oral prodrug of 5-fluorouracil.
  • It manifests due to the cytotoxic effects on rapidly dividing cells in the skin of the hands and feet.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cyclophosphamide: This drug can cause several side effects including hematological and bladder toxicity but is not commonly associated with hand-foot syndrome.

 

Option B. Chloramphenicol: It is an antibiotic, not used as a chemotherapy agent, and is not linked to this syndrome.

 

Option D. Mitomycin-C: Although it can cause severe bone marrow suppression, it does not typically result in hand-foot syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Patients treated with Capecitabine should be monitored for symptoms of hand-foot syndrome, as early intervention may help manage and potentially mitigate this side effect.

choices.text: Increase in the rate of discharge of the γ efferent neuron
Increased excitability of the motor neuron pool
Decerebration produces no phenomenon akin to spinal shock
Rigidity occurs in all the muscles of the body

questions.text: According to the Herrington classification, which of the following is NOT a characteristic of decerebrate rigidity?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Rigidity occurs in all the muscles of the body

 

  • Decerebrate rigidity, according to Herrington classification, involves several key characteristics, but not all muscles of the body exhibit rigidity.
  • The hallmark signs include increased excitability of the motor neuron pool, increased discharge of γ efferent neurons, and a lack of spinal shock phenomenon following decerebration.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increase in the rate of discharge of the γ efferent neuron: Correctly describes that decerebration does not lead to a flaccid paralysis phase like spinal shock, which supports why this choice is characteristic of decerebrate rigidity.

 

Option B. Increased excitability of the motor neuron pool: Accurately describes the increased excitability due to loss of inhibitory signals from the brain, a key feature of decerebrate rigidity.

 

Option C. Decerebration produces no phenomenon akin to spinal shock: Correctly describes that decerebration does not lead to a flaccid paralysis phase like spinal shock, which supports why this choice is characteristic of decerebrate rigidity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Decerebrate rigidity is characterized by increased excitability of the motor neuron pool and increased discharge of γ efferent neurons, but it does not result in rigidity of all the muscles in the body.

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant presents with muscle weakness, cardiomegaly, and respiratory difficulties. Laboratory tests reveal elevated levels of glycogen in the lysosomes. Which enzyme deficiency is responsible for these findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lysosomal acid alpha-glucosidase

 

  • Pompe's disease, also known as glycogen storage disease type II, is caused by a deficiency of the enzyme lysosomal acid alpha-glucosidase (also known as acid maltase).
  • This enzyme is crucial for breaking down glycogen into glucose within the lysosomes.
  • Without this enzyme, glycogen accumulates in the lysosomes, particularly affecting muscle tissues, leading to muscle weakness, cardiomegaly, and respiratory difficulties, as seen in this patient.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Muscle glycogen phosphorylase: Deficiency in this enzyme leads to McArdle disease (glycogen storage disease type V), characterized by muscle cramps and exercise intolerance, not the systemic symptoms seen in Pompe’s disease.

 

Option C. Lactate dehydrogenase: This enzyme is involved in the conversion of lactate to pyruvate in glycolysis. Its deficiency does not cause glycogen accumulation or the symptoms observed in Pompe’s disease.

 

Option D. Phosphofructokinase: Deficiency in this enzyme results in Tarui disease (glycogen storage disease type VII), which primarily causes muscle cramps and hemolysis, not the systemic involvement seen in Pompe’s disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pompe's disease is caused by a deficiency of lysosomal acid alpha-glucosidase, leading to glycogen accumulation in the lysosomes and presenting with muscle weakness, cardiomegaly, and respiratory difficulties.

choices.text: Cystic fibrosis is most often the associated finding
Meconium causes occlusion at DJ flexure
Barium enema is useful for diagnosis
Bishop Koop operation was used for treating meconium ileus

questions.text: A 2-day-old child has still not passed meconium. The pediatrician makes a diagnosis of meconium ileus. Which of the following is incorrect about this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Meconium causes occlusion at DJ flexure  

 

  • ​​​Inspissated meconium pellets usually get stuck at the terminal ileum, not DJ flexure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cystic fibrosis is most often the associated finding:  It leads to pancreatic exocrine insufficiency, leading to failure of digestion of meconium, forming meconium pellets which lead to obstruction at ileum.

 

Option C. Barium enema is useful for diagnosis: The contrast enema shows an unused microcolon. An abdominal radiograph may show a dilated small intestine with mottling. Fluid levels are generally not seen.

 

Option D. Bishop Koop operation was used for treating meconium ileus: The Bishop–Koop operation with its irrigating stoma is now rarely used. Various surgical procedures are used, including intestinal resection and temporary stoma formation, resection and primary anastomosis, and, in uncomplicated cases, enterotomy and irrigation of the bowel.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Correctly understanding and identifying the location of meconium obstruction and its associated conditions and treatment options are critical in pediatric surgical care.
  • The goal is to accurately diagnose and manage meconium ileus, often associated with cystic fibrosis, and recognize that obstruction typically occurs at the terminal ileum, not the DJ flexure.

questions.text: Which method is most appropriate for the disposal of cytotoxic and expired medications to ensure environmental safety and compliance with health regulations?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Incineration

 

  • Incineration is the recommended method for disposing of cytotoxic and expired medications.
  • This process ensures that harmful chemicals and biological properties of the medications are completely destroyed, preventing environmental contamination and reducing the risk of exposure to humans and animals.
  •  Incineration must be conducted under controlled conditions to ensure complete combustion and minimize the release of harmful emissions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dumping: Inappropriate and hazardous, dumping does not neutralize the potentially harmful effects of cytotoxic and expired medications and is illegal under environmental protection laws.

 

Option B. Autoclave: While effective for sterilizing certain medical waste, autoclaving is not sufficient for cytotoxic drugs, as it does not destroy the chemical structure of the medications.

 

Option D. Chemical disinfection: This method is not effective for cytotoxic and expired medications, as it does not ensure complete destruction of the active compounds, which may remain hazardous.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 24-year-old primigravida at 22 weeks of gestation presents to the emergency department with profuse vaginal bleeding. Her blood pressure and glucose levels are within normal limits. Which of the following sites of placental implantation is most likely causing this bleeding?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Internal os

 

  • Profuse vaginal bleeding in the second trimester of pregnancy is most commonly caused by placenta previa, where the placenta implants over or near the internal os of the cervix.
  •  As the cervix begins to dilate and efface in preparation for labor, it can disrupt the placental attachment, leading to significant bleeding.
  • This condition requires careful monitoring and management to prevent complications for both the mother and the fetus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Abdominal: An abdominal pregnancy is a rare form of ectopic pregnancy where the embryo implants outside the uterus. This condition is typically detected earlier in pregnancy and does not present with the described symptoms in the second trimester.

 

Option B. Fallopian tube: Ectopic pregnancies in the fallopian tube usually present much earlier in pregnancy, typically in the first trimester, and can cause severe pain and potentially life-threatening bleeding if the tube ruptures. This is not the cause of second-trimester bleeding.

 

Option D. Ovarian: An ovarian pregnancy is another rare form of ectopic pregnancy that also presents much earlier in pregnancy. It would not cause the described presentation of profuse vaginal bleeding at 22 weeks gestation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Placenta previa, characterized by the placental implantation over the internal os, is a significant cause of profuse vaginal bleeding in the second trimester of pregnancy.

choices.text: Chromosomal nonhomologous crossing over

questions.text: A 57-year-old woman presents with a rapidly growing breast mass. Imaging and biopsy confirm the presence of invasive breast carcinoma. The tumor is evaluated for HER2/neu status using immunohistochemical staining, which shows strong, uniform membrane staining in more than 10% of the tumor cells, as illustrated in the provided image. Which genetic mechanism best explains the observed HER2/neu staining pattern?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Gene amplification

 

  • The strong and uniform staining for HER2/neu indicates overexpression of the HER2 protein, typically due to gene amplification.
  • In breast cancer, HER2/neu gene amplification leads to an increased number of copies of the HER2 gene, resulting in overproduction of the HER2 protein on the cell surface.
  • This mechanism is associated with more aggressive tumor behavior and can be targeted with specific therapies such as trastuzumab.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Polyploidy: Polyploidy refers to cells containing more than two complete sets of chromosomes. While it can be a feature of cancer cells, it does not specifically account for the overexpression of HER2/neu protein.

 

Option B. Chromosomal nonhomologous crossing over: Chromosomal nonhomologous crossing over involves the exchange of genetic material between nonhomologous chromosomes and is not related to the specific overexpression of HER2/neu.

 

Option D. Aneuploidy: Aneuploidy refers to an abnormal number of chromosomes. While aneuploidy is common in cancer cells, it does not specifically result in HER2/neu overexpression.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The overexpression of HER2/neu in breast cancer is most commonly due to gene amplification, which leads to increased HER2 protein on the cell surface and can be detected by strong, uniform staining in immunohistochemical analysis.

questions.text: A 53-year-old man presents with worsening dyspnea and cough. Despite treatment, he succumbs to respiratory failure. An autopsy is performed, revealing the lung pathology shown in the image. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis based on the autopsy findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Panacinar emphysema

 

  • Panacinar emphysema is characterized by uniform destruction and enlargement of the acini, affecting the entire alveolus distal to the terminal bronchiole.
  • This type of emphysema typically results in large, confluent airspaces, as seen in the autopsy image.
  • Panacinar emphysema is commonly associated with alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency, which predisposes patients to extensive lung damage and respiratory failure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chronic bronchitis: Chronic bronchitis is marked by chronic inflammation, mucous gland hyperplasia, and excessive mucus production, leading to airway obstruction. It does not produce the large airspaces seen in panacinar emphysema.

 

Option B. Bronchiectasis: Bronchiectasis involves permanent dilation of bronchi and bronchioles due to chronic infection and inflammation, presenting with dilated airways filled with mucus and pus. It does not result in the uniform airspace enlargement seen in panacinar emphysema.

 

Option D. Centriacinar emphysema: Centriacinar emphysema predominantly affects the central parts of the acini, sparing the distal alveoli, and is typically seen in smokers. It primarily affects the upper lobes and presents with a different pattern of lung damage than panacinar emphysema.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Panacinar emphysema, associated with alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency, is characterized by uniform destruction and enlargement of the acini throughout the entire alveolus, resulting in large, confluent airspaces and leading to severe respiratory impairment.

choices.text: Decreased acetylcholine release at the nerve endings
Increased acetylcholine release at the nerve endings
Increased synaptic transmission at the myoneural junction
Decreased synaptic transmission at the myoneural junction

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents to the clinic with complaints of muscle weakness and fatigue that worsen with activity and improve with rest. She reports difficulty chewing and double vision by the end of the day. Physical examination reveals ptosis and weak neck muscles. Based on the clinical presentation, which of the following is most likely associated with her condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Decreased synaptic transmission at the myoneural junction

 

  • Myasthenia gravis is a neuromuscular disorder characterized by weakness and fatigability of skeletal muscles, which worsen with activity and improve with rest.
  • It is caused by autoantibody-mediated destruction of the acetylcholine receptors (AChRs) at the neuromuscular junction.
  • This leads to a decreased transmission at the neuromuscular (myoneural) junction, resulting in the typical symptoms of fluctuating muscle weakness, ptosis, and diplopia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Decreased acetylcholine release at the nerve endings: This is incorrect as myasthenia gravis involves the destruction of acetylcholine receptors, not a decrease in acetylcholine release.

 

Option B. Increased acetylcholine release at the nerve endings: This is not associated with myasthenia gravis. The problem lies with the receptors, not the release of acetylcholine.

 

Option C. Increased synaptic transmission at the myoneural junction: This is incorrect because myasthenia gravis involves decreased synaptic transmission due to the destruction of receptors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Myasthenia gravis is an autoimmune disorder that leads to the destruction of acetylcholine receptors at the neuromuscular junction, resulting in decreased synaptic transmission and characteristic symptoms of fluctuating muscle weakness and fatigue

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents with facial erythema. She reports using a cream for fairness and to reduce brown blemishes on her cheeks, which is helping in reducing blemishes, but her redness is increasing, especially on exposure to the sun. She also experiences a burning sensation and irritation on her face. On examination, erythematous papules are seen over the face along with erythema. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Rosacea

 

  • The patient's symptoms and presentation are characteristic of rosacea, a chronic skin condition that causes facial erythema, especially in the central face, and is often triggered by sun exposure.
  • The use of certain topical products, such as fairness creams which can contain steroids, can aggravate the condition, leading to increased redness, burning, and irritation.
  • The presence of erythematous papules also supports the diagnosis of rosacea.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lupus erythematosus: Lupus typically presents with a malar rash (butterfly-shaped rash) across the cheeks and nose but does not usually cause erythematous papules. It is also associated with systemic symptoms and positive serological markers like ANA.

 

Option B. Drug hypersensitivity: Drug hypersensitivity reactions can cause rashes and erythema but are usually widespread rather than limited to the face. They also often present with systemic symptoms.

 

Option C. Polymorphous light eruption: This condition is a photosensitivity reaction that causes itchy, red papules or plaques on sun-exposed areas. It is usually episodic and triggered by sun exposure but does not typically cause the persistent facial erythema and irritation seen in rosacea.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Rosacea is characterized by facial erythema, papules, and sensitivity, often exacerbated by sun exposure and certain topical products.
  • Proper diagnosis and management are essential to control symptoms and prevent aggravation.

questions.text: Which vector is responsible for transmitting the disease kala azar?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sandfly

 

Kala azar/ leishmaniasis caused by the parasite Leishmania donovani.

Symptoms and Lab findings for diagnosis: The presence of macrophages loaded with organisms containing kinetoplasts, along with the systemic symptoms of fever, hepatosplenomegaly, and pancytopenia, are characteristic of this disease.

 

 

A. Splenomegaly seen in visceral leishmaniasis; B. Hypopigmented skin changes in early PKDL; C and D. Extensive facial nodular lesions in late PKDL

 

 

L. donovani amastigotes: showing a macrophage containing multiple Leishmania amastigotes. A. Schematic; B. In bone marrow smear stained with Giemsa. Note that each amastigote has a nucleus (red arrow) and a rod-shaped kinetoplast (black arrow)

 

Transmission: Visceral leishmaniasis is transmitted by the bite of the infected female Phlebotomus sandfly. This disease is particularly prevalent in regions of India such as Bihar, West Bengal, Jharkhand, and Uttar Pradesh, aligning with the patient's location.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tse-Tse fly: This fly is the vector for Trypanosoma brucei, which causes African trypanosomiasis or sleeping sickness, not visceral leishmaniasis.

 

Option C. Triatomine bug: Known for transmitting Trypanosoma cruzi, the causative agent of Chagas disease, primarily found in Latin America.

 

Option D. Female Anopheles mosquito: This mosquito is the vector for malaria, caused by Plasmodium species, and does not transmit Leishmania.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Diseases transmitted by sandfly:

  • Visceral leishmaniasis
  • Sand-fly fever (Papatasi fever/3 days fever)
  • Oriental sore
  • Oroya fever (Carrion’s disease).

choices.text: May follow upper respiratory infection
ESR and white blood cell counts are usually normal
Ultrasound of the joint reveals widening of the joint space
The hip is typically held in adduction and internal rotation

questions.text: Transient synovitis (toxic synovitis) of the hip is characterized by all of the following, except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) The hip is typically held in adduction and internal rotation

 

TRANSIENT (TOXIC) SYNOVITIS OF HIP

 

  • It is self-limiting, inflammatory condition of synovium.
  • It is the common cause of hip pain and limping in children of 6 to 12 years of age.
  • Boys are affected 2-3 times more than girls.
  • 95% cases are unilateral.
  • A recent history of an upper respiratory tract infection of viral origin is usually present.
  • The joint is held in flexion, abduction and external rotation because in this position, the joint capacity is maximum (so stretching due to effusion is minimal), thus causing least pain.
  • Physical examination is characterized by guarded rotation of hip joint.
  • Pain can be elicited at the extreme of motion.
  • The patient is non-toxic and rarely have temperature above 38˚C or any indications of systemic illness.
  • The white blood cells (WBC) count, C-reactive protein level, and erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) levels are usually within normal limits.
  • Radiographs are normal or have slightly widened joint space medially.
  • Ultrasound reveals mild effusion and widening of joint space.
  • Joint aspiration usually reveals a WBC count between 5,000 and 15,000 cells/mL, with more than 25% polymorphonuclear leukocytes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The transient synovitis of the hip is usually a manifestation after an upper respiratory tract infection.
  • On physical examination, the hip joint is held in flexion, abduction and external rotation position (FABER).
  • ESR and WBC levels are usually within normal limits.
  • Ultrasound investigation of the hip reveals mild effusion and widened joint space.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the psychiatry clinic with complaints of restlessness and an inability to sit still. He was recently started on antipsychotic medication for schizophrenia. Since starting the medication, he has felt an inner sense of restlessness and was seen moving his legs and pacing around the room. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Akathisia

 

  • Akathisia is a common side effect of antipsychotic medications, characterized by an inner sense of restlessness and an inability to sit still.
  • Patients often describe it as an uncomfortable urge to move, leading to behaviors such as pacing, leg movements, or shifting positions frequently.
  • This condition can be very distressing and is commonly seen shortly after the initiation or increase in dosage of antipsychotic drugs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tardive dyskinesia: This is a late-onset movement disorder caused by prolonged use of antipsychotics, characterized by repetitive, involuntary movements, such as grimacing, tongue movements, and lip-smacking. It does not typically present with restlessness.

 

Option B. Acute dystonia: This is a sudden and often painful muscle contraction that can occur shortly after starting antipsychotic treatment. It commonly affects muscles of the neck, face, and back, but it does not cause a sense of restlessness or pacing.

 

Option D. Parkinsonism: This refers to symptoms similar to Parkinson’s disease, including tremors, bradykinesia, rigidity, and postural instability, resulting from antipsychotic medication. It does not include a sense of inner restlessness.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Akathisia is characterized by a sense of inner restlessness and objective, observable movements such as fidgeting of legs, pacing around, and inability to sit or stand in one place for a long time.
  • They can present soon after starting the antipsychotic or after dosage adjustments.
  • It is the most common extrapyramidal side effect of antipsychotics. The drug of choice is Propranolol (beta blockers).

choices.text: Clinical trials to prove adverse effects of drugs
Clinical trials to prove safety of drugs
Use of various research findings for making decisions about the best patient care
All of the above

questions.text: Evidence-based medicine (EBM) is a critical aspect of modern medical practice. Which of the following best describes the concept of evidence-based medicine?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Use of various research findings for making decisions about the best patient care

 

Evidence-based medicine involves the integration of the best available research evidence with clinical expertise and patient values to make decisions about the care of individual patients.

 

While it includes clinical trials that assess the safety and adverse effects of drugs, it encompasses a broader range of scientific studies and data sources to inform clinical decisions, not limited only to drug safety or adverse effects.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Clinical trials to prove adverse effects of drugs: This is a component of evidence-based medicine, but it does not encompass all aspects of EBM.

 

Option B. Clinical trials to prove safety of drugs: Like option A, this is also a part of EBM, focusing specifically on drug safety.

 

Option D. All of the above: Although clinical trials for safety and adverse effects are components of EBM, the best description of EBM is its holistic approach to integrating diverse research findings into clinical decision-making.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Evidence-based medicine is a comprehensive approach that uses a wide array of empirical evidence, including but not limited to clinical trials, to inform best practices for patient care.
  • This approach ensures that clinical decisions are well-supported by the latest and most robust scientific evidence.

questions.text: Who is credited with pioneering the concept of 'specific protection by vaccine,' which laid the foundational principles of immunization practices?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Chinese medicine

 

Chinese medicine is recognized for pioneering the concept of specific protection by vaccine through the practice of variolation.

 

Before the modern era of vaccination, ancient Chinese practitioners used variolation to inoculate individuals against smallpox.

 

This early form of immunization involved introducing material from smallpox sores into the skin of healthy individuals to induce a mild disease form and confer immunity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Robert Koch: Known for his groundbreaking work in microbiology and establishing Koch's postulates, which link specific pathogens to specific diseases, but not specifically for vaccine development.

 

Option C. Ambroise Pare: A French surgeon known for his advancements in surgical techniques and wound care, not immunization.

 

Option D. Louis Pasteur: Although Louis Pasteur is a key figure in the development of several vaccines, such as those for rabies and anthrax, the concept of specific protection by vaccine traces back to earlier Chinese practices.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The early practice of variolation in Chinese medicine represents one of the first forms of vaccination, showcasing an innovative approach to disease prevention that predates modern immunological science.

choices.text: β-blockers are contraindicated in pheochromocytoma.
Salt and fluid intake should be restricted.
IV phentolamine is indicated for hypertensive crisis.
Surgery is rarely required.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with episodes of severe headaches, palpitations, and sweating. Her blood pressure is 210/120 mmHg. After initial stabilization, laboratory tests confirm elevated plasma metanephrines. Which of the following statements is true regarding the management of pheochromocytoma?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Salt and fluid intake should be restricted.

  • The management of pheochromocytoma includes ensuring adequate volume status, usually by encouraging liberal salt and fluid intake, contrary to the answer provided.
  • This helps to avoid hypotension during surgery.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. β-blockers are contraindicated in pheochromocytoma: β-blockers should be used only after adequate α-blockade to avoid unopposed alpha-adrenergic receptor stimulation, which can worsen hypertension.

 

Option C. IV phentolamine is indicated for hypertensive crisis : This is correct for hypertensive crisis but is not the best answer related to general management strategies.

 

Option D. Surgery is rarely required : Surgery is the definitive treatment for pheochromocytoma, making this statement incorrect.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Pheochromocytoma requires careful preoperative management with α-blockade followed by β-blockade.
  • Adequate volume expansion with salt and fluid intake is essential to prevent intraoperative hypotension.
  • Definitive treatment involves surgical removal of the tumor.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman with a history of chronic pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) presents with abdominal pain and abnormal uterine bleeding. Long-standing pelvic inflammation may lead to which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pyometra

 

  • Long-standing pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) can result in several complications due to the chronic inflammation and infection of the reproductive organs.
  • One such complication is pyometra, which is the accumulation of pus within the uterine cavity.
  •  Chronic PID can cause scarring and obstruction of the cervical canal, leading to the inability of pus to drain, thereby resulting in pyometra.
  • Patients with pyometra may present with symptoms like abdominal pain, abnormal uterine bleeding, and foul-smelling vaginal discharge.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Uterine polyposis: Uterine polyps are benign growths that arise from the endometrium. They are not typically associated with chronic pelvic inflammatory disease.

 

Option B. Pseudocyesis: Pseudocyesis, or false pregnancy, is a psychological condition where a woman believes she is pregnant and may exhibit some physical signs of pregnancy. It is not related to chronic pelvic inflammatory disease.

 

Option D. Endometrial hyperplasia: Endometrial hyperplasia is a condition characterized by the thickening of the endometrium, often due to prolonged estrogen stimulation without progesterone opposition. It is not a direct consequence of chronic PID.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Long-standing pelvic inflammatory disease can lead to pyometra, which is the accumulation of pus within the uterus due to chronic inflammation and infection.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with a history of chronic gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) undergoes the surgical procedure depicted in the image. Identify the most common complication of this procedure:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dysphagia

 

  • The surgical procedure shown in the image is a fundoplication, commonly performed to treat GERD.
  • The most common complication following a fundoplication is short term dysphagia, which occurs due to the wrap causing edema, making it difficult for food to pass through the esophagus into the stomach.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Recurrence of symptomatic reflux: While a potential complication, recurrence of reflux is less common than dysphagia immediately after surgery.

 

Option C. Esophageal perforation: This is a serious but rare complication of fundoplication.

 

Option D. Infections: Infections can occur but are not as common as dysphagia in patients undergoing this procedure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Short term dysphagia is the most common complication following fundoplication surgery for GERD.
  •  It is essential to monitor patients for this issue postoperatively and manage it promptly to ensure optimal recovery and function.

questions.text: In evaluating the effectiveness of the malaria surveillance system under the National Vector Borne Disease Control Programme, which parameter is most commonly used to assess the system's efficiency?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Annual Blood Examination Rate

 

  • The Annual Blood Examination Rate (ABER) is a crucial parameter for assessing the efficiency of malaria surveillance systems.
  • It measures the percentage of the population from which blood smears are taken to test for malaria parasites annually.
  • This rate helps to determine the surveillance system’s ability to screen the population for malaria, thus reflecting the system's reach and thoroughness in monitoring and controlling malaria within the community.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Annual Parasite Index: Although this parameter measures the incidence rate of confirmed malaria cases per 1,000 persons at risk in a year, it does not directly reflect the efficiency of surveillance activities.

 

Option C. Slide positivity rate: This measures the proportion of examined blood slides that are found positive for malaria parasites. While it indicates the level of malaria transmission, it does not directly assess the efficiency of the surveillance system itself.

 

Option D. Slide falciparum rate: Specifically measures the proportion of malaria cases caused by Plasmodium falciparum among the positive slides, useful for understanding the disease's epidemiology but not the surveillance efficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Lying flat with neck extended
Lying flat with neck flexed

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient is scheduled for an elective abdominal surgery. During the preoperative assessment, the anesthesiologist decides to insert a nasogastric (NG) tube to decompress the stomach and prevent aspiration. What is the best position for the patient during the insertion of the NG tube?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sitting with neck flexed

 

  • The best position for inserting a nasogastric (NG) tube in a conscious patient is sitting with neck flexed.
  • This position helps direct the tube towards the esophagus and prevents it from coiling in the oropharynx or entering the trachea.
  • Flexion of the neck aligns the esophagus and the tube pathway, facilitating easier and safer insertion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lying flat with neck extended: Extending the neck in a flat position increases the risk of the tube entering the trachea rather than the esophagus, which can lead to complications such as aspiration.

 

Option B. Lying flat with neck flexed: Although neck flexion helps in directing the tube towards the esophagus, lying flat can make the insertion process more challenging and uncomfortable for a conscious patient.

 

Option D. Sitting with neck extended: Extending the neck while sitting also increases the likelihood of the tube entering the trachea, increasing the risk of aspiration and other complications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • For safe and effective insertion of a nasogastric (NG) tube in a conscious patient, the best position is sitting with neck flexed.
  •  This position helps guide the tube towards the esophagus, reducing the risk of misplacement and associated complications.

choices.text: Ductal carcinoma in situ

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman presents with a palpable breast mass that she noticed 2 months ago. On physical examination, the mass is described as soft and jelly-like, measuring 6 cm in diameter. A biopsy is performed, and histologic examination of the breast tissue is shown in the image. What is the appropriate diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Colloid carcinoma

 

  • Colloid carcinoma, also known as mucinous carcinoma, is a subtype of invasive breast cancer characterized by the production of abundant extracellular mucin.
  • The histologic image shows clusters of tumor cells floating in pools of mucin, which is a hallmark feature of this type of carcinoma.
  • Clinically, these tumors tend to be soft and gelatinous due to the high mucin content.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lobular carcinoma: Lobular carcinoma is characterized by small, uniform cells arranged in a single-file pattern or in a targetoid growth around ducts. It does not produce the extracellular mucin seen in colloid carcinoma.

 

Option B. Ductal carcinoma in situ: Ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) is characterized by the proliferation of malignant cells within the ductal system without invasion of the surrounding stroma. It typically does not produce the mucinous features seen in colloid carcinoma.

 

Option C. Tubular carcinoma: Tubular carcinoma is characterized by well-differentiated tubular structures infiltrating the stroma. It is typically a low-grade carcinoma and does not produce the abundant extracellular mucin characteristic of colloid carcinoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Colloid carcinoma (mucinous carcinoma) of the breast is characterized by tumor cells floating in pools of extracellular mucin, resulting in a soft, gelatinous mass.
  • This histologic finding is key to diagnosing this subtype of breast cancer.

choices.text: Lobular carcinoma of the breast

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman with a strong family history of breast and ovarian cancers undergoes genetic testing and is found to have a BRCA1 gene mutation. Which of the following types of cancer is she at the highest risk of developing?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Triple-negative breast cancer

 

  • Individuals with BRCA1 mutations are at a higher risk of developing triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC), which is characterized by the absence of estrogen receptors (ER), progesterone receptors (PR), and HER2 expression.
  • TNBC is typically more aggressive and has fewer treatment options compared to other breast cancer subtypes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lobular carcinoma of the breast: Although BRCA1 mutation carriers can develop various types of breast cancer, lobular carcinoma is less common compared to ductal carcinoma, which includes triple-negative breast cancer.

 

Option B. Well-differentiated breast cancer: Well-differentiated breast cancers are less aggressive and typically associated with positive hormone receptor status, which is not typical for BRCA1 mutation carriers.

 

Option C. HER2-positive breast cancer: HER2-positive breast cancer is more commonly associated with BRCA2 mutations rather than BRCA1 mutations.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • BRCA1 mutation carriers are at a higher risk of developing triple-negative breast cancer, which is more aggressive and lacks hormone receptors and HER2 expression.
  • This makes it less responsive to hormonal therapies and targeted treatments available for other breast cancer subtypes.

choices.text: Harpenden caliper for skin fold thickness

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy is referred to a pediatric clinic for evaluation due to concerns about his growth. During the assessment, the healthcare provider uses an instrument shown in the image. What aspect of growth is this instrument used to measure?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Harpenden caliper for skin fold thickness

 

  • The Harpenden caliper is specifically designed to measure skinfold thickness, which helps in assessing body fat percentage.
  • It is widely used in growth assessments to evaluate nutritional status and body composition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Joule’s caliper: Not a standard instrument used in growth measurement.

 

Option C. Infantometer for length: Used to measure the length of infants, not skin fold thickness.

 

Option D. Stadiometer for height: Used to measure height, not skin fold thickness.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Harpenden caliper is used to measure skin fold thickness, an important parameter for assessing body fat and nutritional status in children.

choices.text: The dose of telmisartan should be reduced in severe renal failure but not in hepatic failure.
The dose of irbesartan should be reduced in case of severe hepatic failure but not in renal failure.
The dose of olmesartan should be reduced in severe liver failure as well as in renal failure.
Losartan acts as a thromboxane A2 antagonist and inhibits platelet aggregation.

questions.text: The true statement among the following is:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Losartan acts as a thromboxane A2 antagonist and inhibits platelet aggregation.

 

  • Losartan is an Angiotensin Receptor Blocker. It binds to the AT1 receptor with high affinity.
  • It is also a competitive antagonist of the thromboxane A2 receptor and attenuates platelet aggregation.
  • All ARBs are avoided in moderate to severe renal impairment due to risk of development of hyperkalemia.
  • Most ARBs require dose adjustment in moderate to severe hepatic impairment also except LEO (Safe in Liver disease are Eprosartan and Olmesartan)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The dose of telmisartan should be reduced in severe renal failure but not in hepatic failure: Like all the ARBs, telmisartan is avoided in severe renal disease. Further, telmisartan is excreted by biliary secretion. So, dose of telmisartan should be reduced in mild to moderate hepatic failure. 

 

Option B. The dose of irbesartan should be reduced in case of severe hepatic failure but not in renal failure: Irbesartan is avoided in both severe renal and hepatic disease.

 

Option C. The dose of olmesartan should be reduced in severe liver failure as well as in renal failure: Olmesartan require dose adjustment in severe renal failure. However, olmesartan and eprosartan do not require dose adjustment even in severe liver failure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • All ARBs should be avoided in moderate to severe renal disease due to risk of hyperkalemia.
  • Except Olmesartan and Eprosartan, all other ARBs require dose adjustment in moderate to severe hepatic disease also.
  • Losartan has additional antiplatelet action by acting as TXA2 receptor antagonist.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents to the clinic with complaint of excessive handwashing and fear of contamination that have been progressively worsening over the past year. She reports spending several hours each day washing her hands, to the point where her skin is raw and bleeding. These behaviors are significantly interfering with her daily life, including her job and social interactions. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Exposure and response prevention (ERP)

 

  • Exposure and response prevention (ERP) is considered the gold standard treatment for obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD).
  • It involves exposing the patient to feared situations and preventing compulsive responses.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT): This is incorrect. While CBT is effective for many anxiety disorders, ERP is a specialized form of CBT specifically designed for OCD and is considered more effective.

 

Option C. Psychodynamic therapy: This is incorrect. Psychodynamic therapy focuses on unconscious processes and past experiences, which is not the first-line treatment for OCD.

 

Option D. Supportive therapy: This is incorrect. Supportive therapy provides general emotional support but does not specifically target the symptoms of OCD.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • For OCD, Exposure and Response Prevention (ERP), a specialized form of CBT, is the evidence-based first-line treatment.
  • It involves exposing patients to their obsessional triggers while refraining from performing their compulsive rituals, gradually reducing the distress elicited by obsessions.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old man presented with an acute onset of chest pain radiating to the left arm and diaphoresis. His ECG and cardiac biomarkers show non-ST elevation myocardial infarction. Which of the following will be used in the treatment of this patient?

 

1. Atorvastatin 

2. Aspirin 

3. Clopidogrel 

4. Low molecular weight heparin 

5. Alteplase
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 2, 3, 4

 

Explanation: 

 

In the management of non-ST elevation myocardial infarction (NSTEMI), several medications are routinely used to reduce the risk of further ischemic events and manage the condition effectively:

 

1. Atorvastatin: High-intensity statin therapy is recommended to lower cholesterol levels and stabilize atherosclerotic plaques.

 

2. Aspirin: This antiplatelet agent is essential for reducing clot formation and preventing further arterial blockage.

 

3. Clopidogrel: Another antiplatelet agent, often used in combination with aspirin, to provide dual antiplatelet therapy (DAPT), which is beneficial in preventing further ischemic events.

 

4. Low molecular weight heparin: Anticoagulant therapy, such as enoxaparin, is crucial in preventing thrombus formation and managing NSTEMI. Enoxaparin is typically administered subcutaneously at a dose of 1 mg/kg twice daily.

 

Other Options:

 

5. Alteplase: This thrombolytic agent is used in the management of ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI) when percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) is not immediately available. It is not indicated for NSTEMI due to the lack of ST elevation and the associated risks of bleeding without significant benefit.

 

Educational Objective :

 

For NSTEMI management, the treatment includes Atorvastatin, Aspirin, Clopidogrel, and Low molecular weight heparin. Thrombolytic agents like Alteplase are reserved for STEMI with specific indications.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child presents with a high fever, difficulty breathing, and stridor. An X-ray of the neck is given below. Which of the following is false regarding the condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Expiratory stridor is seen

 

  • Expiratory stridor is typically not associated with supraglottic infections like epiglottitis.
  • In such conditions, inspiratory stridor is more commonly observed due to upper airway obstruction.
  • The characteristic symptoms and signs include difficulty breathing, high fever, and the child adopting the tripod position to ease breathing.
  • Hemophilus influenzae type B (Hib) is a common causative agent.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Breathing difficulty is seen: This is true, as the inflammation can lead to significant airway obstruction causing difficulty in breathing.

 

Option C. Hemophilus influenzae causes it: This is true, as Hib is a well-known cause of epiglottitis.

 

Option D. Tripod sign is seen: This is true, as children with epiglottitis often adopt a tripod position to help open their airway and ease breathing.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In supraglottic infections like epiglottitis, inspiratory stridor, not expiratory stridor, is typically seen.
  • Recognizing the signs, such as the "thumb" sign on X-ray and the child's tripod positioning, is crucial for prompt diagnosis and treatment, especially since Hemophilus influenzae is a common causative agent.

questions.text: Based on the provided image, identify the specific surgical step being illustrated in Image A.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Capsulorrhexis

 

  • The image depicts the procedure of capsulorrhexis, a critical step in conventional extracapsular cataract extraction (ECCE).
  • Capsulorrhexis involves creating a circular opening in the anterior capsule of the lens, often performed using a fine needle or forceps.
  • This step is crucial for gaining access to the lens for subsequent removal.
  • The technique aims for a continuous, curvilinear tear, which is preferred over other methods such as the can-opener technique or linear capsulotomy due to its ability to maintain capsule integrity and reduce the risk of radial tears.

 

Further Details:

  • Continuous Curvilinear Capsulorrhexis (CCC): This technique is considered superior because it provides a controlled and contained opening that minimizes the risk of tearing and provides a strong, intact capsule for intraocular lens (IOL) placement.
  • Visualization: Trypan blue dye may be used to enhance visibility of the capsule during this delicate procedure.
  • Subsequent Steps: After capsulorrhexis, hydrodissection is typically performed to separate the corticonuclear mass from the capsular bag, followed by the phacoemulsification or manual removal of the lens nucleus and cortex, and finally, the placement of an intraocular lens (IOL).


 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hydrodissection: Hydrodissection is the process of injecting a balanced salt solution between the lens capsule and the lens material to separate the cataract from the capsule. This step follows capsulorrhexis in cataract surgery. It facilitates the removal of the lens by allowing it to be freely rotated and mobilized within the capsule.

 

Option C. Intraocular lens implantation: Intraocular lens (IOL) implantation is the step where an artificial lens is placed inside the eye after the removal of the natural lens. This usually happens after the lens material has been completely removed, including the nucleus and the cortical material. The IOL is typically inserted into the capsular bag that originally housed the natural lens.

 

Option D. Lens aspiration: Lens aspiration involves the removal of the lens material from the eye, using either a manual or mechanical suction device. This process occurs after capsulorrhexis and hydrodissection have been completed. It includes the aspiration of both the nucleus and the cortical material of the lens to clear the visual axis and prepare the eye for the insertion of an IOL.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Capsulorrhexis is a foundational step in modern cataract surgery, setting the stage for the safe removal of the lens and implantation of an IOL, ensuring better outcomes for patients undergoing cataract extraction.

questions.text: Which ligament is primarily responsible for maintaining the anteversion of the uterus during pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Round ligament

 

  • The round ligament plays a crucial role in maintaining the anteverted position of the uterus during pregnancy.
  •  It extends from the uterine horns, passes through the inguinal canal, and attaches to the labia majora.
  • This ligament helps to keep the uterus tilted forward (anteverted), particularly as the uterus enlarges during pregnancy.
  •  The stretching and tension of the round ligament provide support to maintain the uterus in this position.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Uterosacral ligament: This ligament provides support to the uterus by attaching it to the sacrum. It helps to prevent excessive forward movement of the uterus but does not primarily maintain anteversion.

 

Option B. Cardinal ligament: Also known as the transverse cervical ligament, this ligament provides lateral support to the uterus and cervix but is not primarily responsible for maintaining the uterus in an anteverted position.

 

Option D. Pubocervical ligament: This ligament supports the bladder and anterior vaginal wall, contributing to the stability of the pelvic floor but not specifically to the anteversion of the uterus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The round ligament is primarily responsible for maintaining the anteversion of the uterus during pregnancy.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents with headaches, vomiting, and difficulty with coordination. Imaging studies reveal a mass in the cerebellum. A biopsy of the mass is performed, and histopathological examination confirms the diagnosis of desmoplastic medulloblastoma. Desmoplastic medulloblastoma is associated with which of the following syndrome:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Gorlin syndrome

 

  • Desmoplastic medulloblastoma is a variant of medulloblastoma that is associated with Gorlin syndrome (nevoid basal cell carcinoma syndrome).
  • Gorlin syndrome is an autosomal dominant disorder characterized by multiple basal cell carcinomas, jaw cysts, skeletal abnormalities, and an increased risk of developing medulloblastomas, particularly the desmoplastic variant.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cowden disease: Cowden disease, also known as PTEN hamartoma tumor syndrome, is characterized by multiple hamartomas and an increased risk of breast, thyroid, and endometrial cancers. It is not associated with desmoplastic medulloblastoma.

 

Option B. Gardner syndrome: Gardner syndrome is a variant of familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) characterized by multiple colorectal polyps, osteomas, epidermoid cysts, and soft tissue tumors. It is not associated with medulloblastoma.

 

Option D. Turcot syndrome: Turcot syndrome is characterized by the association of colorectal polyposis (as seen in FAP or Lynch syndrome) with primary brain tumors, particularly glioblastomas and medulloblastomas. While medulloblastomas can occur in Turcot syndrome, the desmoplastic variant is specifically associated with Gorlin syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Desmoplastic medulloblastoma is associated with Gorlin syndrome (nevoid basal cell carcinoma syndrome), which is characterized by multiple basal cell carcinomas, jaw cysts, and skeletal abnormalities.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male is brought to the emergency department after a motor vehicle accident. His blood pressure is 90/60 mmHg. Examination shows he is stable, GCS 15/15, reactive pupils, and tenderness with bruising and petechiae over the left lower chest wall. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) eFAST

 

  • eFAST (extended Focused Assessment with Sonography for Trauma) is a rapid bedside ultrasound examination used to detect free fluid (which may indicate hemorrhage) or other injuries in trauma patients.
  • Given the patient’s hypotension (BP 90/60 mm Hg), tenderness, and bruising over the left lower chest wall, an eFAST is the most appropriate next step to quickly assess for possible internal injuries, such as hemoperitoneum or hemothorax, that might require urgent intervention.
  • Despite the patient being hemodynamically stable with a GCS of 15/15 and reactive pupils, the presence of these physical signs warrants an immediate and thorough evaluation for internal injuries.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CECT (Contrast-Enhanced Computed Tomography): While CECT is an excellent imaging modality to evaluate for internal injuries, it is not the first step in a hemodynamically unstable patient. It requires transporting the patient to the radiology department, which might delay necessary immediate interventions.

 

Option C. Intubation: This procedure is typically reserved for patients with compromised airways, altered mental status, or significant respiratory distress. Given this patient’s GCS of 15/15 and reactive pupils, intubation is not immediately necessary.

 

Option D. Exploratory laparotomy: This invasive surgical procedure is usually reserved for patients with clear signs of severe intra-abdominal injury or when non-invasive diagnostic methods (like eFAST) are unavailable or inconclusive. In this stable patient with a GCS of 15/15, it would be premature to perform exploratory laparotomy without further diagnostic imaging.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In trauma patients presenting with hypotension and signs of potential internal injury, eFAST is the most appropriate initial diagnostic tool to quickly assess for life-threatening conditions.

questions.text: A 47-year-old male presents to the clinic complaining of fatigue and joint pain. He reports a history of excessive alcohol consumption and has a family history of liver disease. Physical examination reveals hepatomegaly, increased skin pigmentation, and arthritis in multiple joints. MRI abdomen was performed. What is the likely diagnosis based on the T2w MRI image shown below:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Primary hemochromatosis

 

  • The patient's symptoms of fatigue, joint pain, increased skin pigmentation (bronzing), hepatomegaly, and a family history of liver disease suggest a diagnosis of primary hemochromatosis, which is an autosomal recessive disorder causing increased intestinal iron absorption and progressive iron overload in the liver, pancreas, skin, joints, and other organs.
  • The MRI T2-weighted image typically shows increased signal intensity in the liver due to iron deposition, which can cause a loss of the normal signal seen on T2w images due to the paramagnetic effects of iron.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hemosiderosis: This refers to iron deposition that occurs due to exogenous sources, such as multiple blood transfusions. It differs from hereditary hemochromatosis in the absence of tissue damage.

 

Option B. Wilson disease: This is a disorder of copper metabolism and would not show iron deposition on MRI; it would instead potentially show hepatic damage and basal ganglia changes in the brain on imaging.

 

Option D. Osteopetrosis: This is a genetic bone disorder characterized by increased bone density and would not present with liver abnormalities or skin pigmentation changes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The clinical presentation of joint pain, skin pigmentation, hepatomegaly, fatigue, and family history of liver disease, in conjunction with findings on T2-weighted MRI, is indicative of primary hemochromatosis.
  • This is a genetic disorder of iron metabolism leading to abnormal iron accumulation in various organs, which can be visualized using MRI due to the paramagnetic properties of iron.

choices.text: Build healthy public policy
Strengthen community action for health
Build social security system
Reorient health services

questions.text: According to the Ottawa Charter for Health Promotion, which of the following is NOT identified as a key action area?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Build social security system

 

The Ottawa Charter for Health Promotion outlines five key action areas: building healthy public policy, strengthening community action for health, reorienting health services, developing personal skills, and creating supportive environments.

 

Building a social security system, while important for overall social determinants of health, is not listed as one of the specific action areas in the Charter.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Build healthy public policy: This involves creating policies that support health at all levels of governance, directly influencing the conditions necessary for health.

 

Option B. Strengthen community action for health: This action emphasizes the power of community efforts and capacity building to enhance health outcomes through collective action.

 

Option D. Reorient health services: This focuses on adjusting the health services to focus more on the total needs of the individual as a whole rather than just treating diseases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

OTTAWA charter for health promotion

questions.text: A 33-year-old male presents with difficulty in lifting the front part of his foot, a condition known as foot drop. This condition often results from nerve injury. Which nerve, when injured, results in foot drop?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Common peroneal nerve

 

  • The common peroneal nerve (also known as the common fibular nerve) is responsible for innervating the muscles that perform dorsiflexion of the foot, primarily the tibialis anterior, extensor hallucis longus, and extensor digitorum longus.
  • Injury to the common peroneal nerve disrupts the function of these muscles, leading to foot drop, characterized by the inability to lift the front part of the foot, resulting in a dragging foot gait.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Femoral nerve: The femoral nerve innervates the muscles of the anterior thigh, such as the quadriceps, which are involved in knee extension. It does not affect dorsiflexion of the foot, so injury to this nerve does not cause foot drop.

 

Option C. Tibial nerve: The tibial nerve innervates the muscles of the posterior compartment of the leg, which are responsible for plantarflexion (pointing the toes downward) and inversion of the foot. Injury to this nerve would not result in foot drop.

 

Option D. Sciatic nerve: The sciatic nerve is a large nerve that branches into the tibial and common peroneal nerves. While injury to the sciatic nerve can cause a wide range of motor and sensory deficits in the lower limb, foot drop specifically is more directly associated with injury to the common peroneal nerve.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Injury to the common peroneal nerve results in foot drop, characterized by the inability to dorsiflex the foot due to paralysis of the muscles innervated by this nerve.

choices.text: It arises from Sacral Plexus
Emerges from the Medial Border of Psoas Major
The Anterior Branch of this nerve contributes to Patellar Plexus

questions.text: A 51-year-old female presents with pain, tingling, and numbness over the upper thigh. Upon examination, the neurologist identifies the condition as meralgia paresthetica. Which of the following statements is true about the nerve responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) The Anterior Branch of this nerve contributes to Patellar Plexus

 

  • Meralgia paresthetica is caused by compression or entrapment of the lateral femoral cutaneous nerve, which is purely a sensory nerve.
  • This nerve arises from the lumbar plexus (L2-L3) and typically passes beneath the inguinal ligament, near the anterior superior iliac spine (ASIS).
  • While the lateral femoral cutaneous nerve primarily provides sensation to the anterolateral thigh, the anterior branch of this nerve also contributes to the patellar plexus, providing sensory innervation around the patellar area.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It arises from Sacral Plexus: The lateral femoral cutaneous nerve arises from the lumbar plexus, specifically from the L2 and L3 nerve roots, not the sacral plexus.

 

Option B. Emerges from the Medial Border of Psoas Major: The lateral femoral cutaneous nerve typically emerges from the lateral border of the psoas major muscle, not the medial border.

 

Option C. Passes beneath Fascia Iliaca: While the lateral femoral cutaneous nerve does pass beneath the inguinal ligament, it is not commonly described as passing beneath the fascia iliaca.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The lateral femoral cutaneous nerve, responsible for meralgia paresthetica, arises from the lumbar plexus (L2-L3) and the anterior branch of this nerve contributes to the patellar plexus, providing sensory innervation to the anterolateral thigh and around the patellar area.

questions.text: According to the 2020 guidelines from the National Institute of Nutrition (NIN) in India, what is the recommended dietary allowance (RDA) for iodine intake among lactating women?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 280 μg/day

 

  • The National Institute of Nutrition (NIN) specifies that lactating women should consume 280 micrograms (μg) of iodine per day.
  • This recommendation is based on the increased nutritional needs during lactation to support both maternal health and infant development, ensuring sufficient iodine for thyroid function and hormone production, which is critical for both the mother and the breastfeeding infant.

 

Educational Objective:

 

NIN guidelines on recommended dietary allowance

questions.text: A child presents with a left to right shunt and high output cardiac failure. The following is his MRI. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vein of Galen malformation

 

  • Vein of Galen malformation is a rare vascular anomaly in the brain, often identified in infants or children, characterized by an abnormal arteriovenous connection.
  • This malformation can lead to a left to right shunt and high output cardiac failure due to the increased blood flow through the malformation.
  • The MRI typically shows an enlarged vein of Galen with abnormal connections to surrounding blood vessels, consistent with the image provided.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Dandy Walker syndrome: This condition involves a congenital brain malformation affecting the cerebellum and the fluid-filled spaces around it. It typically presents with symptoms of increased intracranial pressure and cerebellar dysfunction, not with a left to right shunt or high output cardiac failure.

 

Option C. Pneumocephalus: This is the presence of air within the cranial cavity, usually resulting from trauma or surgical procedures. It does not cause a left to right shunt or high output cardiac failure.

 

Option D. Venous sinus thrombosis: This condition involves a blood clot in the dural venous sinuses, leading to increased intracranial pressure and possible stroke-like symptoms. It does not typically present with a left to right shunt or high output cardiac failure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Vein of Galen malformation is characterized by an abnormal arteriovenous connection in the brain, leading to high output cardiac failure and left to right shunt, and can be identified on MRI.

choices.text: Skin, supraspinous ligament, interspinous ligament, dura mater, arachnoid mater
Skin, subcutaneous tissue, supraspinous ligament, epidural space, dura mater
Skin, subcutaneous tissue, supraspinous ligament, interspinous ligament, ligamentum flavum, epidural space, dura mater, arachnoid mater
Skin, subcutaneous tissue, interspinous ligament, ligamentum flavum, subdural space, arachnoid mater

questions.text: During the administration of spinal anesthesia, which of the following is the correct order of layers pierced by the needle?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Skin, subcutaneous tissue, supraspinous ligament, interspinous ligament, ligamentum flavum, epidural space, dura mater, arachnoid mater

 

  • Correct. This is the accurate sequence of layers that the needle pierces during spinal anesthesia, from the outermost to the innermost layer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Skin, supraspinous ligament, interspinous ligament, dura mater, arachnoid mater: Incorrect. While this option lists several layers, it omits the subcutaneous tissue and ligamentum flavum and incorrectly skips the epidural space.

 

Option B. Skin, subcutaneous tissue, supraspinous ligament, epidural space, dura mater: Incorrect. This option fails to include the interspinous ligament and the arachnoid mater.

 

Option D. Skin, subcutaneous tissue, interspinous ligament, ligamentum flavum, subdural space, arachnoid mater: Incorrect. The subdural space is not typically pierced during spinal anesthesia, and the ligamentum flavum is not included in the list.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The proper sequence of anatomical layers pierced during spinal anesthesia is skin, subcutaneous tissue, supraspinous ligament, interspinous ligament, ligamentum flavum, epidural space, dura mater, and arachnoid mater.

questions.text: A 42-year old patient underwent cystoscopy, which revealed multiple yellow-white plaques in the trigone of the bladder. The histopathology image is provided. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Malakoplakia

 

  • Malakoplakia is characterized by the presence of yellow-white plaques in the bladder mucosa, often in the trigone area.
  • Histologically, it features large histiocytes (von Hansemann cells) with basophilic inclusions called Michaelis-Gutmann bodies, which are pathognomonic for this condition.
  • These inclusions are due to defective phagocytosis of bacteria, typically Escherichia coli, leading to a chronic granulomatous inflammatory response.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A.  Interstitial cystitis: Interstitial cystitis, also known as painful bladder syndrome, typically presents with chronic pelvic pain, urinary urgency, and frequency. Cystoscopic findings may include glomerulations (pinpoint hemorrhages) but not yellow-white plaques. Histologically, it shows inflammatory infiltrates, mast cells, and fibrosis.

 

Option C. Polypoid cystitis: Polypoid cystitis is a reactive inflammatory condition of the bladder often associated with chronic irritation, such as from indwelling catheters. It is characterized by the presence of polypoid projections of the mucosa but does not present with yellow-white plaques or the histological features seen in malakoplakia.

 

Option D. Acute cystitis: Acute cystitis presents with symptoms of urinary tract infection, such as dysuria, frequency, and urgency. Cystoscopic findings typically show erythematous and edematous mucosa with petechial hemorrhages. Histologically, it is characterized by neutrophilic infiltration but lacks the hallmark features of malakoplakia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Malakoplakia is identified by the presence of yellow-white plaques in the bladder and histologically by the presence of von Hansemann cells and Michaelis-Gutmann bodies, indicative of a chronic granulomatous inflammatory response to bacterial infection.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy presents with recurrent chest infections, failure to grow and frequent bulky, greasy stools. On evaluation, the chloride concentration in his sweat is found to be 65 mEq/L. Which of the following is most likely to be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hyponatremic hypochloremic alkalosis

 

  • The clinical scenario is suggestive of cystic fibrosis, a condition where patients commonly exhibit hyponatremic hypochloremic alkalosis.
  • Excessive loss of salt in the sweat predisposes young children to episodes of salt depletion.
  • Therefore, these children present with hypochloremic alkalosis due to increased serum bicarbonate levels.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hyponatremic hyperchloremic alkalosis: Incorrect, as hyperchloremia is not typically seen in cystic fibrosis.

 

Option B. Hypernatremic hyperchloremic acidosis: Incorrect, as this electrolyte imbalance does not fit the typical presentation of cystic fibrosis.

 

Option D. Hypernatremic hypochloremic acidosis: Incorrect, as cystic fibrosis patients are more likely to present with alkalosis rather than acidosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In cystic fibrosis, patients often present with hyponatremic hypochloremic alkalosis due to excessive loss of salt in sweat, leading to episodes of salt depletion and increased serum bicarbonate levels.

questions.text: Which of the following nerves is associated with the developmental origin of second brachial arch?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Facial nerve

 

  • The facial nerve (cranial nerve VII) is the nerve that develops from the second brachial (pharyngeal) arch.
  • During embryological development, the second brachial arch gives rise to several structures, including the muscles of facial expression, the stapes, the styloid process, and part of the hyoid bone.
  • The facial nerve is responsible for innervating these muscles and providing sensory and autonomic functions related to the structures derived from this arch.

 

 

Other Options:
