Option A. Glossopharyngeal nerve: The glossopharyngeal nerve (cranial nerve IX) is associated with the third brachial arch, not the second. It innervates structures derived from the third arch, such as the stylopharyngeus muscle.

 

Option B. Trigeminal nerve: The trigeminal nerve (cranial nerve V) is associated with the first brachial arch, not the second. It innervates muscles derived from the first arch, such as the muscles of mastication.

 

Option D. Vagal nerve: The vagal nerve (cranial nerve X) is associated with the fourth and sixth brachial arches, not the second. It innervates structures derived from these arches, including the muscles of the larynx and pharynx.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The facial nerve (cranial nerve VII) develops from the second brachial arch and is responsible for innervating the muscles of facial expression and other structures derived from this arch.

choices.text: 24 hours later but within 72 hrs
More than 2 mg/dL conjugated bilirubin

questions.text: Which of the following is not a criterion of pathological jaundice in newborns?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 24 hours later but within 72 hrs

 

  • Pathological jaundice in newborns is characterized by jaundice presenting within the first 24 hours of life, jaundice persisting beyond 14 days, a conjugated bilirubin level greater than 2 mg/dL, or the presence of clay-colored stools.
  • Jaundice that appears 24 hours later but within 72 hours typically falls within the range of physiological jaundice, which is a normal phenomenon in newborns as their liver matures and processes bilirubin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. 14 days persistence: Jaundice persisting beyond 14 days is considered pathological and warrants further investigation.

 

Option C. More than 2 mg/dL conjugated bilirubin: Elevated levels of conjugated bilirubin greater than 2 mg/dL are indicative of pathological jaundice and suggest a possible underlying liver or biliary tract disorder.

 

Option D. Clay colored stool: The presence of clay-colored stool is a sign of biliary obstruction or liver dysfunction, both of which are associated with pathological jaundice.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pathological jaundice in newborns is characterized by its early onset within the first 24 hours, persistence beyond 14 days, elevated conjugated bilirubin levels, or the presence of clay-colored stools.

questions.text: A patient with HIV, aged 35, complains of discomfort and creamy lesions in the mouth, as shown in the image. On microscopic analysis of these plaques shows the presence of budding yeasts and structures resembling pseudohyphae. What diagnosis best fits this clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Oral candidiasis

 

  • The symptoms described, including the creamy white lesions that can be removed to expose a red base, along with the identification of budding yeasts and pseudohyphae on microscopic examination, strongly point to oral candidiasis.
  • This fungal infection is common in individuals with compromised immune systems, such as those with HIV, where normal fungal flora proliferates uncontrollably.
  • Oral candidiasis typically responds to antifungal treatments.

 

Other Options:

 

Options B. Hairy leukoplakia: This condition is characterized by white, hairy patches on the tongue, often seen in immunocompromised individuals but does not involve yeast or pseudohyphae.

 

Options C. Lichen planus: Features lacy white patches typically on the mucosa, not associated with fungal infections and lacking yeast forms.

 

Options D. Diphtheria: Presents with a grey pseudomembrane over the throat and tonsils, caused by a bacterial infection and not associated with yeast.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Oral candidiasis involves noting the typical removable white plaques and confirming fungal etiology through microscopic identification of Candida, emphasizing the importance of prompt and appropriate antifungal treatment for symptomatic relief and infection control in immunocompromised patients.

choices.text: For ligation of uterine artery during hysterectomy

questions.text: Based on the options provided, the most likely use of this instrument is:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) For tubal ligation

 

  • The instrument depicted in the image is a laparoscopic grasper, commonly used in various laparoscopic surgeries, including tubal ligation.
  •  Tubal ligation is a permanent form of contraception where the fallopian tubes are occluded to prevent pregnancy.
  • During this procedure, laparoscopic graspers are essential for holding and manipulating the fallopian tubes to achieve occlusion.
  • This minimally invasive technique involves accessing the fallopian tubes through small abdominal incisions, using the grasper to manipulate the tubes effectively.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ectopic pregnancy: While laparoscopic graspers can be used in the management of ectopic pregnancies to manipulate tissues and remove the ectopic pregnancy, the primary indication of the instrument in the image is not specifically for this purpose.

 

Option B. For ligation of uterine artery during hysterectomy: Although laparoscopic graspers are used in hysterectomy procedures, they are not specifically designed for ligating the uterine artery. This procedure typically requires specialized instruments such as laparoscopic clips or bipolar coagulation devices.

 

Option C. Ovarian cystectomy: Laparoscopic graspers can be used to manipulate ovarian tissues and cysts during an ovarian cystectomy. However, the removal of ovarian cysts often requires more specialized instruments like laparoscopic scissors and dissectors for precise surgical removal.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Laparoscopic graspers are versatile instruments primarily used in gynecological procedures such as tubal ligation, where they play a crucial role in grasping and manipulating the fallopian tubes for effective occlusion.

choices.text: Cleaning and dressing
Debridement and dressing
Cleaning and skin grafting

questions.text: The best way to manage the wound on the knee, after a fall on the road, as shown in the image is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cleaning and dressing

 

  • The image shows an abrasion. Here are some general principles for the management of a superficial abrasion:
  1. Clean the wound: Gently clean the wound with soap and warm water to remove any dirt or debris. Use a clean cloth or sterile gauze to pat the wound dry.
  2. Apply a dressing: Cover the abrasion with a sterile dressing or adhesive bandage to keep it clean and protected. Change the dressing daily or more often if it becomes wet or dirty.
  3. Manage pain: Over-the-counter pain relievers such as acetaminophen or ibuprofen can help relieve pain and reduce inflammation.
  4. Watch for signs of infection: Keep an eye on the abrasion for signs of infection such as redness, swelling, pus, or increasing pain. Seek medical attention if you suspect the wound may be infected.
  5. Avoid further injury: Try to avoid activities that may cause further injury or irritation to the affected area. If the abrasion is in a location that may be easily irritated or injured, consider using protective clothing or bandages.
  6. Follow up: Depending on the severity of the abrasion, you may need to follow up with a healthcare provider for further evaluation and treatment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Debridement and dressing: Debridement is not necessary for superficial abrasions unless there is significant foreign material embedded in the wound.

 

Option C. Cleaning and skin grafting: Skin grafting is not indicated for superficial abrasions as they typically heal well with conservative management.

 

Option D. Flap reconstruction: Is required for deep wounds with poor vascularity.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • For superficial abrasions, the best management includes cleaning the wound, applying a sterile dressing, managing pain, monitoring for infection, avoiding further injury, and following up as needed.

questions.text: A 40-year-old waste management worker has jaundice, red eyes, and blood in the urine. Which diagnostic test should be conducted to confirm the suspected infectious disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Microscopic agglutination test

 

The patient’s occupational exposure combined with symptoms such as abdominal pain, jaundice, conjunctival suffusion, and hematuria suggests the likelihood of leptospirosis.

 

The Microscopic Agglutination Test (MAT) is the most appropriate diagnostic test for this condition as it specifically detects antibodies against different serovars of Leptospira, confirming the diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Widal test: This test is primarily used for identifying typhoid fever, which typically presents with a gradual onset of fever and gastrointestinal symptoms. It is not suitable for the symptoms and context described here.

 

Option C. Weil-Felix reaction: Employed in the diagnosis of rickettsial infections, characterized by a triad of fever, rash, and headache. It does not align with the patient’s occupational exposure or clinical presentation.

 

Option D. Paul-Bunnell test: Targets the detection of heterophile antibodies associated with infectious mononucleosis, presenting with fever, sore throat, and swollen lymph nodes, which are not consistent with the symptoms reported by the patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Given the specific occupational risks and clinical symptoms of the patient, the Microscopic Agglutination Test is crucial for accurately diagnosing leptospirosis.
  • Early and accurate diagnosis is essential for effective management and treatment of this potentially severe infection.

questions.text: A 30-year-old primigravida in active labor reports a repeated urge to pass urine and experiences premature bearing down. On examination, there is infra-umbilical flattening, and the fetal heart sounds are heard on the lateral side of her abdomen. What is the most likely fetal presentation/position?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Occipito-posterior

 

  • The occipito-posterior (OP) position is characterized by the baby's head being down, but the back of the head (occiput) is towards the mother's back.
  •  This position can cause the mother to feel a repeated urge to pass urine and premature bearing down due to the baby's head pressing against the bladder and rectum.
  •  The infra-umbilical flattening and lateral location of fetal heart sounds are also indicative of this position, as the baby's spine aligns with the mother's spine and the heart sounds are heard laterally.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Knee: A knee presentation is an extremely rare and abnormal fetal position where the knees are presenting first. This would not typically cause the symptoms described, such as the repeated urge to urinate or the specific examination findings.

 

Option C. Right dorso-anterior: In this position, the fetus’s back (dorso) is facing anteriorly and to the right side of the mother. This position would typically result in different auscultation and palpation findings compared to the OP position.

 

Option D. Brow: A brow presentation occurs when the fetal head is partially extended, and the brow is the presenting part. This presentation is usually associated with a larger presenting diameter, making labor more difficult, but does not specifically correlate with the symptoms and signs described in the scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The occipito-posterior position can cause symptoms such as a repeated urge to urinate and premature bearing down, along with infra-umbilical flattening and lateral fetal heart sounds, due to the baby's alignment in the mother's pelvis.

questions.text: According to drug regulatory guidelines, which class of drugs must be sold by retail only upon production of a prescription by a registered medical practitioner?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Schedule H

 

  • Schedule H drugs are those that, due to their potent effects and potential for harm if misused, are regulated such that they must only be dispensed from a pharmacy when accompanied by a valid prescription from a registered medical practitioner.
  • This category includes various antibiotics and other medications that require monitoring by a healthcare provider to ensure safe and effective use.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Schedule G: Contains drugs that must have a label warning but are not specifically restricted to prescription-only sales.

 

Option C. Schedule X: Includes drugs with a high potential for abuse or dependency; however, they require even stricter regulatory handling than Schedule H.

 

Option D. Schedule M: Pertains to the good manufacturing practices (GMP) that facilities must follow when producing pharmaceutical products and does not relate to prescription requirements.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Drugs are broadly of 2 types:

 

  1. Schedule H drugs: Must be sold by retail only when a prescription by registered medical practitioner is produced.
  2. OTC: These are over the counter drugs, which may be sold without prescription.

questions.text: A 23-year-old boy was involved in an argument but quickly worsened into a street brawl with the use of knives. He was examined in the emergency department and found to have a bleeding stab wound in his left flank. A urine specimen revealed frank blood. Of the organs listed below, which one is least likely to be injured?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Inferior vena cava

 

  • Given the location of the injury in the left flank and the presence of blood in the urine, the inferior vena cava (IVC) is the least likely to be injured among the options provided.
  • The IVC is located more centrally and to the right side of the abdominal cavity, making it less susceptible to a left flank injury.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Spleen: The spleen is located in the upper left part of the abdomen and could be injured by a stab wound in the left flank, especially considering its size and proximity to the injury site.

 

Option B. Left suprarenal (adrenal) gland: The left adrenal gland is located atop the left kidney and could be at risk of injury from a stab wound to the left flank, although it is a smaller and more deeply situated organ.

 

Option C. Stomach: Parts of the stomach are also located on the left side of the upper abdomen and could potentially be injured by a stab wound to the left flank, especially if the trajectory of the wound extends more medially.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In the case of a left flank stab wound, the organ least likely to be injured is the inferior vena cava, due to its more central and right-sided location in the abdomen.
  • Other organs located on the left side, such as the spleen, left suprarenal gland, and parts of the stomach, are at higher risk of injury in this scenario.

questions.text: A newborn is evaluated for hypotonia, seizures, and hepatomegaly. Laboratory findings include elevated plasma levels of very long-chain fatty acids. A genetic disorder affecting which of the following cellular organelles is most likely responsible for this presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Peroxisome

 

  • Zellweger syndrome is associated with peroxisome biogenesis disorder.
  • Peroxisomes are critical for various metabolic functions, including the beta-oxidation of very long-chain fatty acids.
  • The absence or malfunction of peroxisomes, as seen in Zellweger syndrome, leads to the accumulation of these fatty acids, which is consistent with the laboratory findings.
  • Clinically, the syndrome presents with severe developmental delays, hypotonia, seizures, and hepatomegaly, all of which are due to the inability to metabolize certain lipids and other substances.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lysosome: Lysosome-related disorders, like lysosomal storage diseases, typically involve the accumulation of metabolites due to defective enzymes within lysosomes but do not primarily affect very long-chain fatty acids.

 

Option C. Mitochondria: Mitochondria are involved in energy metabolism and mitochondrial disorders usually present with muscle weakness, neurological disorders, and lactic acidosis, rather than with the biochemical profile seen in Zellweger syndrome.

 

Option D. Golgi apparatus: Golgi apparatus disorders are extremely rare and typically do not present with the metabolic abnormalities associated with Zellweger syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Zellweger syndrome is a peroxisomal disorder.
  • Clinically, the syndrome presents with severe developmental delays, hypotonia, seizures, and hepatomegaly, all of which are due to the inability to metabolize certain lipids and other substances.

choices.text: Both of the above
None of the above

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman undergoes elective cosmetic surgery after signing an informed consent form that explains the risks, including infection and scarring. She develops an infection post-surgery, which is treated, but she decides to sue for negligence. What type of negligence can the signed informed consent form potentially defend against?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Civil negligence

 

  • In this scenario, the patient's informed consent, which she provided before undergoing elective cosmetic surgery, can serve as a defense against a civil negligence claim.
  • Informed consent means that the patient was made fully aware of the risks and potential complications of the procedure and agreed to proceed.
  • This understanding and agreement can mitigate liability in a civil lawsuit, as the patient had acknowledged and accepted the potential risks, such as infection and scarring.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Criminal Negligence: In criminal negligence, consent is typically not a defense, as criminal negligence implies a higher degree of recklessness or disregard for safety.

 

Option C. Both of the above: Informed consent is primarily relevant as a defense in civil negligence cases.

 

Educational Objective

questions.text: Production of which of the following hormones would be most impaired by lesions that affect the pituitary stalk or hypothalamus?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) ADH

 

The answer is C. (Chap. 371) The pituitary gland weighs ~ 600 mg and is located within the sella turcica ventral to the diaphragma sella; it consists of anatomically and functionally distinct anterior and posterior lobes. The bony sella is contiguous to vascular and neurologic structures, including the cavernous sinuses, cranial nerves, and optic chiasm. Thus, expanding intrasellar pathologic processes may have significant central mass effects in addition to the endocrinologic impact. The posterior pituitary is supplied by the inferior hypophyseal arteries. In contrast to the anterior pituitary, the posterior lobe is directly innervated by hypothalamic neurons (supraopticohypophyseal and tuberohypophyseal nerve tracts) via the pituitary stalk. Thus, posterior pituitary production of vasopressin (antidiuretic hormone) and oxytocin is particularly sensitive to neuronal damage by lesions that affect the pituitary stalk or hypothalamus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ACTH: While ACTH production can be affected, it is typically less sensitive to hypothalamic or pituitary stalk lesions compared to ADH.

 

Option B. Growth hormone: While growth hormone production can be affected, it is typically less sensitive to hypothalamic or pituitary stalk lesions compared to ADH.

 

Option D. Prolactin: Prolactin is unique among pituitary hormones because its primary regulation is inhibitory (by dopamine). Lesions that affect the pituitary stalk can actually lead to increased prolactin levels due to loss of inhibitory control.

 

Educational objective:

 

Production of ADH would be most impaired by lesions that affect the pituitary stalk or hypothalamus

choices.text: Upper GI endoscopy
CECT abdomen angiogram

questions.text: A 65-year-old male smoker with a history of acute myocardial infarction presents with complaints of epigastric and central abdominal pain 30-45 minutes after meals for the past 3 months, accompanied by diarrhea. He has been on long-term proton pump inhibitors without relief. Abdominal examination is normal, and stool routine and abdominal ultrasound are also normal. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) CECT abdomen angiogram

 

  • The patient's presentation of postprandial abdominal pain, diarrhea, and a history of cardiovascular disease is suggestive of chronic mesenteric ischemia.
  • Contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CECT) of the abdomen is the appropriate next step as it can help in diagnosing mesenteric ischemia by visualizing the blood vessels and assessing the extent of ischemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Upper GI endoscopy: This may be used to investigate upper gastrointestinal causes but is less useful in diagnosing mesenteric ischemia.

 

Option B. Colonoscopy: While useful for lower gastrointestinal investigations, it does not help in assessing mesenteric blood flow.

 

Option D. Capsule endoscopy: This is typically performed when endoscopy is normal in cases of GI bleed.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Chronic mesenteric ischemia should be suspected in patients with cardiovascular risk factors presenting with postprandial abdominal pain and unremarkable basic investigations.
  • CECT abdomen is a crucial diagnostic tool to visualize mesenteric blood flow and assess for ischemia.

questions.text: In which trimester does acute fatty liver manifest most commonly during pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Third trimester

 

  • Acute fatty liver of pregnancy (AFLP) is a rare but serious complication that typically manifests in the third trimester of pregnancy.
  •  It is characterized by the accumulation of fat in the liver cells, leading to liver dysfunction.
  •  Symptoms often include nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, jaundice, and malaise.
  •  If left untreated, AFLP can lead to severe liver failure and maternal and fetal morbidity and mortality.
  •  Prompt diagnosis and delivery of the baby are crucial for the management of this condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. First trimester: AFLP does not typically manifest in the first trimester. Symptoms of AFLP are not seen this early in pregnancy.

 

Option B. Second trimester: AFLP is also not commonly seen in the second trimester. The condition generally develops later in pregnancy.

 

Option D. Both (A) and (B): AFLP does not typically occur in either the first or second trimester, making this option incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Acute fatty liver of pregnancy most commonly manifests in the third trimester.

choices.text: Meconium-stained amniotic fluid
Utero placental insufficiency

questions.text: A 25-year-old primigravida with preeclampsia presents with fetal distress and undergoes an emergency cesarean section. After delivery, the uterus appears as shown in the image. What is the most likely cause of the fetal distress?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Abruptio Placenta

 

  • The image shows a uterus with a dark, bruised appearance on the surface, which is indicative of abruptio placentae.
  •  Abruptio placentae, or placental abruption, occurs when the placenta detaches prematurely from the uterine wall, leading to bleeding and compromised blood flow to the fetus.
  • This condition can cause significant fetal distress due to reduced oxygen and nutrient supply.
  •  The clinical setting of preeclampsia, which increases the risk for placental abruption, and the need for emergency LSCS due to fetal distress, strongly support this diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CPD (Cephalopelvic Disproportion): CPD occurs when the baby's head is too large to pass through the mother's pelvis. It is a mechanical issue and would not cause the appearance seen in the image.

 

Option B. Meconium-stained amniotic fluid: This condition indicates fetal distress but does not explain the uterine appearance shown in the image.

 

Option C. Utero placental insufficiency: This condition refers to inadequate blood flow from the placenta to the fetus, typically chronic and without the acute, dramatic appearance of the uterus as seen in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Abruptio placentae is a significant cause of fetal distress and can be identified by the characteristic bruised appearance of the uterus post-delivery, especially in the context of preeclampsia.

questions.text: A 6-year-old male child presents to the emergency department with a 2-week history of fever and fatigue. He has now developed signs of left ventricular dysfunction, including dyspnea and reduced exercise tolerance. A cardiac biopsy is performed, and the histological image is provided. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lymphocytic myocarditis

 

  • The histological image shows myocardial tissue with an infiltrate predominantly composed of lymphocytes, which is characteristic of lymphocytic myocarditis.
  • This type of myocarditis is commonly caused by viral infections such as Coxsackievirus and can present with symptoms like fever, fatigue, and signs of heart failure, including left ventricular dysfunction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pyogenic myocarditis: Pyogenic myocarditis, caused by bacterial infections, would show a predominance of neutrophils rather than lymphocytes in the myocardial infiltrate. The image does not show neutrophilic infiltration, which rules out this diagnosis.

 

Option C. Chagas disease: Chagas disease, caused by the protozoan Trypanosoma cruzi, typically presents with amastigotes in myocardial cells. The biopsy image does not show these characteristic features of Chagas disease.

 

Option D. Acute rheumatic fever: Acute rheumatic fever usually presents with Aschoff bodies in the myocardium, which are granulomatous nodules, and is part of a pancarditis involving all layers of the heart. The image does not show these specific features.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Lymphocytic myocarditis is characterized by the presence of lymphocytic infiltrates in the myocardial tissue and can present with symptoms such as fever, fatigue, and signs of left ventricular dysfunction, as seen in the provided histological image.

questions.text: A 48-year-old male with chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) on imatinib therapy presents with increasing splenomegaly and leukocytosis. BCR-ABL1 kinase domain mutation analysis reveals a T315I mutation. Which of the following tyrosine kinase inhibitors (TKIs) is most likely to be effective in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ponatinib

 

  • The T315I mutation in the BCR-ABL1 kinase domain is a major mechanism of resistance to first- and second-generation TKIs such as imatinib, dasatinib, nilotinib, and bosutinib.
  • Ponatinib is a third-generation TKI specifically designed to inhibit BCR-ABL1 with the T315I mutation and has shown efficacy in patients with this mutation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dasatinib, B. Nilotinib, and C. Bosutinib: These are first- and second-generation TKIs that are ineffective against the T315I mutation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Ponatinib is the tyrosine kinase inhibitors (TKIs) most likely to be effective in this patient of CML on imatinib therapy presenting with increasing splenomegaly and leukocytosis.

questions.text: During diagnostic laparoscopy for chronic abdominal pain and diarrhoea, the small bowel was noted to have findings as shown. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Crohn’s disease

 

  • The image from the diagnostic laparoscopy shows characteristic features of Crohn’s disease, which often involves creeping fat over small intestine, particularly the terminal ileum.
  • The hallmark of Crohn’s disease includes transmural inflammation, which can lead to strictures, fistulas, and "cobblestone" appearance of the mucosa.
  • These findings are not typical for the other conditions listed.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. TB: Intestinal tuberculosis can present with strictures and ulcers, but it often involves the ileocecal region and has caseating granulomas which are not typically observed in Crohn's disease.

 

Option C. Diverticuli: Diverticuli are outpouchings of the colon wall, typically found in the large intestine, particularly the sigmoid colon, and are not seen as transmural lesions in the small intestine.

 

Option D. Ulcerative colitis (UC): Ulcerative colitis primarily affects the colon and rectum with continuous mucosal inflammation and does not involve the small intestine or show transmural inflammation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Crohn’s disease is characterized by creeping fat over small intestine and transmural inflammation of the gastrointestinal tract, most commonly affecting the terminal ileum and colon.
  • It can present with strictures, fistulas, and a cobblestone appearance on endoscopy, differentiating it from ulcerative colitis and other gastrointestinal conditions.

choices.text: C fibers are more sensitive to pressure than A fibers.
A fibers are more sensitive to hypoxia than B fibers.
A fibers are more susceptible to pressure changes than C fibers.
A fibers are more susceptible to hypoxia than C fibers.

questions.text: A person wakes up in the morning with paresis in his arm after sleeping with the arm under the head but does not experience numbness. Which of the following is the best explanation for this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) A fibers are more susceptible to pressure changes than C fibers.

 

  • The lack of numbness but presence of paresis suggests that motor function (controlled by A fibers) is affected while sensory function (often involving C fibers) remains intact.
  • A fibers, which include motor neurons, are larger and myelinated, making them more susceptible to pressure changes.
  • When pressure is applied, such as from sleeping on an arm, A fibers are more likely to be compressed, leading to temporary motor dysfunction (paresis).
  • However, C fibers, which are smaller and unmyelinated, are less affected by pressure and continue to function, explaining the absence of numbness.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. C fibers are more sensitive to pressure than A fibers: This statement is incorrect. C fibers are less affected by pressure compared to A fibers.

 

Option B. A fibers are more sensitive to hypoxia than B fibers: This statement is unrelated to the given scenario as the issue is pressure-related rather than hypoxia-related.

 

Option D. A fibers are more susceptible to hypoxia than C fibers: While A fibers may be more susceptible to hypoxia, this is not the primary factor in the scenario described. The paresis is due to pressure, not hypoxia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A fibers, which include motor neurons, are more susceptible to pressure changes than C fibers, leading to temporary paresis without numbness when compressed.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department with a history of recurrent bacterial infections. Physical examination reveals growth retardation and distinctive facial features. Laboratory tests show the presence of anti-A, anti-B, and anti-H antibodies. Which of the following disorders is most likely associated with these findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) LAD II

 

  • Leukocyte adhesion deficiency (LAD) II is characterized by a defect in the fucosylation process required for the synthesis of the H antigen on red blood cells.
  • This defect leads to the presence of anti-H antibodies, along with anti-A and anti-B antibodies.
  • Clinically, patients present with recurrent bacterial infections, growth retardation, and distinctive facial features due to the impaired immune response and defective leukocyte adhesion and migration.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bruton's hypogammaglobulinemia: Also known as X-linked agammaglobulinemia, this condition is characterized by a lack of B cells and immunoglobulins, leading to recurrent bacterial infections. However, it is not associated with anti-H antibodies or blood group antibodies.

 

Option B. LAD I: Leukocyte adhesion deficiency I is due to a defect in the integrin β2 chain (CD18), leading to impaired leukocyte adhesion and migration. It presents with recurrent bacterial infections but does not involve anti-H antibodies.

 

Option C. LAD III: Leukocyte adhesion deficiency III involves a defect in the signaling pathway for integrin activation. It presents with recurrent infections and bleeding tendencies, but it is not associated with anti-H antibodies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • LAD II is characterized by recurrent bacterial infections, growth retardation, and distinctive facial features due to a defect in fucosylation leading to the presence of anti-H antibodies and impaired leukocyte adhesion and migration.

questions.text: In assessing skin manifestations associated with viral infections, which of the following does not typically exhibit a widespread morbilliform rash?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Herpes zoster

 

  • Herpes zoster, also known as shingles, is characterized by a painful, localized vesicular rash that follows a dermatomal distribution, not a morbilliform pattern.
  • This type of rash is specific to the reactivation of the varicella-zoster virus and differs significantly from the generalized, flat, or slightly raised red lesions typical of morbilliform rashes that are seen in infections such as measles, rubella, and dengue.

 

Morbilliform pattern Rash

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dengue: This viral infection can feature a morbilliform rash alongside other symptoms such as fever, headache, and severe muscle pain.

 

Option B. Rubella: Known for its distinct pink or light red rash, which starts on the face and quickly spreads downward, covering the body in a morbilliform pattern.

 

Option D. Measles: Prominently displays a morbilliform rash that begins on the face and spreads to cover most of the body, often accompanied by koplik spots in the mouth.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Herpes zoster's unique presentation of a painful, localized rash along nerve pathways helps differentiate it from other diseases that cause more generalized morbilliform rashes.

questions.text: In the setting of a tropical disease research expedition, a scientist develops fever and a rash after returning from an area with a recent Zika virus outbreak. What diagnostic test is considered the most definitive for identifying an active Zika virus infection in this individual?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Real-Time Reverse Transcriptase PCR (RT-PCR)

 

  • For accurate and rapid diagnosis of Zika virus in individuals showing early symptoms such as fever and rash, Real-Time Reverse Transcriptase PCR (RT-PCR) is the definitive test.
  • This molecular technique is capable to detect the presence of Zika virus RNA in blood and urine samples, offering high sensitivity during the acute phase of infection.
  • This test is particularly valuable in a research or outbreak scenario, allowing for timely medical responses and epidemiological tracking.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Standard PCR: While useful for DNA viruses, for RNA viruses like Zika, RT-PCR, which includes a reverse transcription step, is necessary to convert RNA into DNA for amplification.

 

Option B. Plaque reduction neutralization test: This serological test measures the level of virus-neutralizing antibodies and is more useful for retrospective confirmation of Zika virus exposure rather than immediate diagnosis.

 

Option C. Detection of IgM antibodies: While the presence of IgM antibodies indicates recent exposure to Zika virus, this test may yield cross-reactions with other flaviviruses and is less specific than RT-PCR for diagnosing an active infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Real-Time RT-PCR is crucial for diagnosing Zika virus in symptomatic individuals, particularly in regions affected by an outbreak or in cases involving travelers returning from such areas.
  • It provides a quick and specific diagnosis, essential for effective public health management and patient care.

choices.text: 1, 2, and 3 are correct
1, 3, and 4 are correct
1, 2, and 4 are correct
1, 2, 3, and 4 are correct

questions.text:
Which of the following aspects are typically targeted by disease control measures?

 

 

  1. Reducing the incidence of disease
  2. Lowering the financial burden to the community
  3. Alleviating the effects of infection, including both physical and psychological complications
  4. Shortening the duration of disease and its transmission
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 2, 3, and 4 are correct

 

Disease control involves comprehensive strategies that not only aim to reduce the incidence of disease (1) but also seek to decrease the economic impact of diseases on communities (2).

 

Additionally, effective disease control measures address the wide-ranging effects of infections by managing both the physical and psychological complications (3) and by reducing the duration of disease and limiting its spread (4).

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Disease control: Is reducing the transmission of disease agent to such a low level that it ceases to be a public health problem; it aims at reducing,
  1. Incidence of the disease
  2. Duration of the disease
  3. Effects of infection
  4. Financial burden to the community

questions.text: A 38-year-old male presents with mucoid discharge from urethra associated with dysuria since 2 days. He had an unprotected sexual exposure 14 days back. The treatment of choice would be:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Azithromycin

 

  • The presentation of urethral discharge and dysuria following unprotected sexual exposure is highly suggestive of a sexually transmitted infection (STI).
  • Given the symptoms and the timing of exposure, the diagnosis is likely non-gonococcal urethritis (NGU), which is commonly caused by Chlamydia trachomatis.
  • The recommended treatment for NGU is azithromycin 1 gram taken as a single dose.
  • Azithromycin is effective against Chlamydia trachomatis, which is a common cause of non-gonococcal urethritis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cefixime: Cefixime is effective against Neisseria gonorrhoeae but is not the first-line treatment for non-gonococcal urethritis. It is typically used in combination with azithromycin to cover potential co-infection with chlamydia.

 

Option B. Penicillin: Penicillin is not effective against chlamydia or the common causes of non-gonococcal urethritis. It is primarily used for the treatment of syphilis.

 

Option D. Cotrimoxazole: Cotrimoxazole is not recommended for the treatment of non-gonococcal urethritis or the common pathogens causing it.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The recommended treatment for non-gonococcal urethritis, often caused by Chlamydia trachomatis, is azithromycin 1 gram taken as a single dose.

choices.text: Decreased metabolism of vitamin K
Increase in Protein C
Loss of antithrombin III (AT III)

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient with a history of nephrotic syndrome presents with symptoms of unexplained swelling and recent episodes of leg pain. Laboratory tests show hypoalbuminemia and proteinuria. The physician suspects a hypercoagulable state. What is the cause of hypercoagulation in this nephrotic syndrome?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Loss of antithrombin III (AT III)

 

  • In nephrotic syndrome, there is significant proteinuria, leading to the loss of several important proteins in the urine.
  • One of these proteins is antithrombin III (AT III), a crucial inhibitor of thrombin and other clotting factors.
  • The loss of AT III results in a hypercoagulable state, increasing the risk of thrombosis in these patients.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Decreased metabolism of vitamin K: Decreased metabolism of vitamin K is not a feature of nephrotic syndrome. Vitamin K is essential for the synthesis of several clotting factors, but its metabolism is not directly affected in nephrotic syndrome.

 

Option B. Increase in Protein C: Protein C is a natural anticoagulant. An increase in Protein C would lead to a reduced risk of thrombosis, which is the opposite of what occurs in nephrotic syndrome.

 

Option D. Decreased fibrinogen: Fibrinogen levels are typically normal or increased in nephrotic syndrome. Decreased fibrinogen would lead to a bleeding tendency rather than a hypercoagulable state.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In nephrotic syndrome, the hypercoagulable state is primarily caused by the loss of antithrombin III (AT III) in the urine, which impairs the body's ability to inhibit thrombin and other clotting factors, thereby increasing the risk of thrombosis.

questions.text: A mother brings her 10-month-old baby to the OPD with vomiting, severe jaundice, hepatomegaly and features of irritability on starting weaning with fruit juice. Which of the following enzymes is defective?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Aldolase B

 

  • The symptoms described in the 10-month-old baby—vomiting, severe jaundice, hepatomegaly, and irritability upon introduction of fruit juice—are characteristic of hereditary fructose intolerance (HFI).
  • This disorder arises from a deficiency in the enzyme Aldolase B, which is crucial for the metabolism of fructose.
  • When fructose is ingested (such as from fruit juices), it cannot be properly metabolized, leading to the accumulation of fructose-1-phosphate in the liver, which causes severe hypoglycemia and other metabolic disturbances.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Fructokinase: Fructokinase deficiency leads to fructosuria, which is generally a benign condition where fructose is excreted in the urine without serious systemic effects like those described.

 

Option C. Glucose 6 phosphatase: Glucose 6 phosphatase deficiency is associated with glycogen storage disease type I (von Gierke disease), which includes severe hypoglycemia, but it is typically not triggered specifically by fructose intake.

 

Option D. Galactose 1 Phosphate Uridyl transferase: Galactose 1 Phosphate Uridyl transferase deficiency leads to galactosemia, which would cause symptoms when lactose (found in milk) is consumed, not fructose from fruit juices.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Hereditary fructose intolerance is a condition resulting from Aldolase B deficiency.

questions.text: A 72-year-old female with congestive heart failure is prescribed furosemide for fluid management. After a few weeks of treatment, blood gas analysis indicates an abnormal acid-base balance. Which type of disturbance is most commonly associated with prolonged use of furosemide?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Metabolic alkalosis

 

  • Furosemide is a loop diuretic that promotes the excretion of sodium, chloride, and water.
  • A common side effect of prolonged use of furosemide is metabolic alkalosis. This condition arises because the diuretic causes significant loss of chloride and sodium in the urine, exceeding the loss of bicarbonate.
  • Furthermore, furosemide induces volume contraction, which leads to increased reabsorption of bicarbonate in the renal tubules.
  • Additionally, secondary hyperaldosteronism due to volume depletion enhances potassium and hydrogen ion loss, contributing further to the alkalotic state.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Respiratory alkalosis: This condition is not directly caused by furosemide. It usually results from hyperventilation, not a diuretic treatment.

 

Option C. Metabolic acidosis: Opposite to the actual effect of furosemide; this condition is characterized by decreased blood bicarbonate, not typically seen with furosemide use.

 

Option D. Respiratory acidosis: This is typically related to hypoventilation and would be unrelated to the effects of furosemide.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • Clinicians should monitor for metabolic alkalosis in patients treated with furosemide, especially when used for an extended period, and manage it appropriately, possibly with adjustments to the diuretic therapy or supplementation of potassium.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man with a history of bronchial asthma, managed with inhaled corticosteroids, complains of painful white patches on his tongue and inner cheeks. He mentions the lesions have been gradually increasing over the past month. Which of the following antifungal agents is most appropriate for treating his condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Clotrimazole

 

  • The patient's symptoms are indicative of oral candidiasis, often seen in individuals using inhaled corticosteroids due to local immunosuppression facilitating fungal overgrowth.
  • Clotrimazole, an azole antifungal, is effective in treating oral candidiasis as it inhibits ergosterol synthesis, disrupting fungal cell membrane formation.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Griseofulvin: This drug targets microtubule function, primarily used against dermatophytes. It is not effective for treating Candida infections, making it an unsuitable choice for this patient.

 

Option C. Terbinafine: Functions by inhibiting squalene epoxidase, affecting ergosterol synthesis. It is typically used for treating dermatophyte infections, such as nail onychomycosis, and is not indicated for oral candidiasis.

 

Option D. Flucytosine: This agent acts on nucleic acid synthesis and is primarily used for systemic fungal infections like cryptococcal meningitis, usually in combination with other antifungals. It is not suitable for treating oral candidiasis.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • Clotrimazole is the preferred topical treatment for oral candidiasis in patients exposed to inhaled corticosteroids, due to its mechanism of disrupting fungal cell membranes by inhibiting ergosterol synthesis.

questions.text: A patient had a femur fracture for which internal fixation was done. Two days later, the patient developed sudden onset shortness of breath with low grade fever. What is the likely cause?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Fat embolism

 

  • Fracture Femur with Breathlessness after 48 hours – think of fat embolism!
  • Fat embolism refers to the presence of fat globules in vital organs and peripheral circulation after fracture of a long bone or other major trauma.
  • Fat embolism syndrome (FES) reflects a serious systemic manifestation as a consequence to these emboli.
  • Fat originates from the site of trauma, particularly from the injured marrow.
  • Fat globules > 10 mm are considered significant.
  • Salient Features:
    • Presence of fat globules in pulmonary circulation.
    • Precipitated by physical trauma such as fracture of long bones, soft tissue trauma, and burns.
  • Clinical Features:
  • Clinical signs and symptoms develop after a asymptomatic latent period of about 12 - 48 hours.
  • Early warning signs are a slight rise in temperature and pulse rate (tachycardia).
  • The classical triad of fat embolism syndrome is:
  • Respiratory symptoms: Dyspnea or tachypnea.
  • Neurological symptoms: Confusion or disorientation.
  • Petechial rash: In axilla, neck, periumbilical area, conjunctiva of lower lid, front and back of chest, shoulder.
  • Diagnosis:
  • FES is distinct from the presence of fat emboli.
  • Symptoms usually occur 1-3 days after a traumatic injury and are predominantly pulmonary (shortness of breath, hypoxemia), neurological (agitation, delirium, or coma), dermatological (petechial rash), and hematological (anemia, low platelets).
  • Diagnostic Criterion for Fat Embolism:

 

 

 

  • 1 major + 4 minor = Fat embolism
  • Treatment:
  • The aim of treatment is maintaining adequate oxygen level in the blood.
  • If necessary, by using intermittent positive pressure ventilation.
  • Oxygen is the only therapeutic tool of proven use.
  • It should be administered in sufficient amount to maintain arterial PO2 > 80 mm Hg.
  • O2 toxicity (pneumonitis) is avoided by using O2 conc. below 40%.
  • Steroids are given to Avoid Pneumonitis.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Pneumothorax: A pneumothorax is a collection of air outside the lung but within the pleural cavity. It occurs when air accumulates between the parietal and visceral pleurae inside the chest. The air accumulation can apply pressure on the lung and make it collapse. Causes of traumatic pneumothorax are penetrating or blunt trauma, rib fracture, diving or flying. While it can cause shortness of breath, it is less likely to occur specifically after femur fracture fixation unless there was a procedure complication.

 

Option B. Pleural effusion: Pleural effusion is the accumulation of fluid in between the parietal and visceral pleura, called the pleural cavity. It can occur by itself or can be the result of surrounding parenchymal disease like infection, malignancy, or inflammatory conditions. While it can cause respiratory symptoms, it is less likely to occur suddenly after femur fracture fixation unless there are other complicating factors.

 

Option D. Congestive cardiac failure: Congestive heart failure (CHF) is a complex clinical syndrome characterized by inefficient myocardial performance, resulting in compromised blood supply to the body. CHF results from any disorder that impairs ventricular filling or ejection of blood to the systemic circulation. Patients usually present with fatigue and dyspnea, reduced exercise tolerance, and systemic or pulmonary congestion. While congestive heart failure can cause shortness of breath, it is less likely to occur suddenly after a femur fracture fixation unless the patient has pre-existing heart conditions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Fat embolism is the most common complication of femur fracture.
  • It usually presents 48 hours after the injury with breathlessness and low grade fever.
  • The patient remains asymptomatic in the initial 12-48 hours.

questions.text: After the successful delivery of a baby, the obstetrician observes that the episiotomy performed has extended backwards beyond the perineal body. Which of the following structures is likely to be injured in this case?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) External anal sphincter

 

  • An episiotomy that extends beyond the perineal body can reach and potentially damage the external anal sphincter.
  •  The external anal sphincter is located posterior to the perineal body and is responsible for controlling the passage of stool.
  • Injury to this muscle can lead to complications such as fecal incontinence.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ischiocavernosus: The ischiocavernosus muscle is located more laterally and anteriorly in the perineum, surrounding the crura of the clitoris or penis. It is not typically at risk with a posterior extension of an episiotomy.

 

Option B. Urethral sphincter: The urethral sphincter is located anteriorly and controls urine flow. It is not at risk from a posterior extension of an episiotomy.

 

Option C. Bulbospongiosus: The bulbospongiosus muscle is located in the perineum but more anteriorly and medially than the external anal sphincter. While it could be affected by a deep episiotomy, it is not as likely to be damaged by a posterior extension.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • An episiotomy that extends beyond the perineal body can injure the external anal sphincter, leading to potential complications such as fecal incontinence.
  • This structure is located posterior to the perineal body and is critical for maintaining continence.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with sudden difficulty speaking after a suspected stroke. Imaging reveals a vascular injury to the inferior frontal gyrus. Which functional area is likely to be affected?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Motor speech area

 

  • The inferior frontal gyrus of the brain is primarily associated with Broca's area, which is responsible for motor speech functions.
  • Broca's area, located in the left hemisphere in most individuals, is crucial for language production and articulation.
  • Damage to this area typically results in Broca's aphasia, characterized by difficulty in speech production while comprehension generally remains intact.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Auditory area: The primary auditory cortex is located in the superior temporal gyrus, not the inferior frontal gyrus.

 

Option B. Visual area: The primary visual cortex is located in the occipital lobe, not in the frontal lobe.

 

Option D. Wernicke's area: Wernicke's area, responsible for language comprehension, is located in the superior temporal gyrus in the posterior part of the temporal lobe, not in the frontal lobe.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The motor speech area, or Broca's area, located in the inferior frontal gyrus, is responsible for language production and is likely to be affected by a vascular injury to this region.

choices.text: Minimal breast-feeding with complementary feeding
Safe & sustainable alternative formula feeds

questions.text: A 28-year-old HIV-positive woman, in a low socio-economic country, who has not been adherent to her antiretroviral therapy (ART) gives birth to a healthy baby girl. During a postnatal visit, the healthcare provider discusses feeding options for the baby considering the mother's HIV status. What is recommended by NACO with regards to feeding the baby?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Exclusive breast-feeding

 

  • NACO recommends exclusive breastfeeding as the infant feeding choice in the first 6 months.
  • This recommendation stands regardless of whether the mother is on ART or the infant is provided with ARV prophylaxis for 6 weeks.
  • The rationale is that breastfeeding should not be mixed with replacement feeds in the first 6 months as it can lead to mucosal abrasions in the baby's gut, facilitating HIV entry.
  • Exclusive breastfeeding minimizes this risk and is considered safer in the context of HIV.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. No breast-feeding: Not recommended as exclusive breastfeeding has benefits and is safer than mixed feeding in the context of HIV.

 

Option B. Minimal breast-feeding with complementary feeding: Mixed feeding is discouraged due to the risk of mucosal abrasions and HIV transmission.

 

Option D. Safe & sustainable alternative formula feeds: Only recommended in resource-rich settings or if exclusive replacement feeding is feasible, sustainable, affordable, and safe, which may not be the case in many settings.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • For HIV-positive mothers, NACO recommends exclusive breastfeeding for the first 6 months to reduce the risk of HIV transmission.
  • Mixed feeding should be avoided due to the increased risk of mucosal abrasions and subsequent HIV entry.
  • Exclusive breastfeeding provides significant benefits and is generally safer for the infant.

choices.text: Sister Mary Joseph nodule

questions.text: A 65-year-old male with early satiety and weight loss was diagnosed with gastric carcinoma. On examination, a swelling was noticed in the left supraclavicular region. What is this known as?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Troisier's sign

 

  • Troisier's sign refers to the presence of a palpable, enlarged left supraclavicular lymph node (Virchow's node), often associated with metastatic gastric carcinoma.
  •  This finding is significant for advanced malignancy and usually indicates metastasis from gastrointestinal or other intra-abdominal cancers.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sister Mary Joseph nodule: This refers to a palpable nodule bulging into the umbilicus, indicating metastasis of an abdominal or pelvic malignancy, most commonly gastrointestinal.

 

Option B. Trousseau syndrome: This sign indicates migratory thrombophlebitis and is often associated with pancreatic and other visceral malignancies.

 

Option D. Krukenberg tumor: This refers to metastatic tumors to the ovaries, typically originating from primary gastrointestinal tract cancers, including gastric carcinoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Troisier's sign is characterized by an enlarged left supraclavicular lymph node, indicating possible metastatic spread from an abdominal malignancy, such as gastric carcinoma.
  • It is a crucial physical finding in patients with suspected advanced gastrointestinal cancer.

questions.text: A 54-year-old woman presents with a foul-smelling, bloody vaginal discharge mixed with mucous. On examination, a necrotizing growth is observed on the cervix with involvement of the lateral parametrium. What is the most appropriate management for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Chemoradiation

 

  • The presentation of a necrotizing cervical growth with lateral parametrium involvement suggests an advanced stage of cervical cancer, likely stage IIB or higher.
  •  In such cases, the standard treatment is concurrent chemoradiation.
  • This involves using both radiation therapy (including external beam radiation and brachytherapy) and chemotherapy (typically cisplatin) to maximize the therapeutic effect and improve patient outcomes.
  • Chemoradiation is effective in reducing tumor size, controlling local disease, and improving survival rates.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Brachytherapy: While brachytherapy is an essential part of the radiation treatment for cervical cancer, it is usually combined with external beam radiation and chemotherapy for advanced stages. It is not used as a sole treatment modality for locally advanced disease.

 

Option B. Chemotherapy: Chemotherapy alone is not sufficient for managing locally advanced cervical cancer. It is used in conjunction with radiation therapy to enhance the overall treatment efficacy.

 

Option C. Surgery: Surgery is typically not indicated for cervical cancer with lateral parametrium involvement (stage IIB or higher) due to the extent of the disease spread beyond the cervix. Concurrent chemoradiation is preferred for better control of the disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • For locally advanced cervical cancer with parametrium involvement, concurrent chemoradiation is the standard and most effective treatment approach.

questions.text: A 7-year-old girl with frequent episodes of staring and unresponsiveness is to start pharmacotherapy. Which medication is considered first-line treatment for her condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D.  Valproic acid

 

The clinical sceranio given above represents the absence seizures. Both valproic acid and ethosuximide are the first line drugs for absence seizures but valproate is the preferred drug.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Carbamazepine is used for focal or tonic-clonic seizures and may worsen absence seizures.

 

Option B. Levetiracetam, though broad-spectrum, is not the traditional first choice for absence seizures.

 

Option C. Ethosuximide is also effective for absence seizures and could be considered, but if both valproate and ethosuximide are given in the options, chose valproate.

 

Educational objective:

 

Valproate is drug of choice for absence seizures.

choices.text: The fingers should be lifted off the chest between compressions.
The thumbs or tips of fingers should remain in contact with the chest during compression and release.
There should be 15 chest compressions and 1 breath per minute.
The pulse should be checked at the carotid artery in infants.

questions.text: A 2-month-old infant is brought to the emergency department unresponsive and not breathing. The medical team immediately starts CPR. When performing chest compressions on an infant, which of the following statements is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) The thumbs or tips of fingers should remain in contact with the chest during compression and release.

 

  • When performing CPR on an infant, it is crucial that the thumbs or tips of fingers remain in contact with the chest during both compression and release to ensure effective compressions and adequate recoil.
  • This method maintains proper chest compression depth and avoids interruptions in blood flow.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The fingers should be lifted off the chest between compressions: Incorrect. Fingers should not be lifted off the chest between compressions to ensure continuous and effective compressions.

 

Option C. There should be 15 chest compressions and 1 breath per minute: Incorrect. The recommended ratio for infant CPR is 30 chest compressions and 2 breaths per minute (or 100-120 compressions per minute) when there is only one rescuer, and 15:2 when a second rescuer is present.

 

Option D. The pulse should be checked at the carotid artery in infants: Incorrect. In infants, the pulse should be assessed at the brachial artery, not the carotid artery. For age 1 to adolescence it should be carotid artery

 

Educational Objective

 

  • In infant CPR, maintain contact with the chest during compressions and releases, use a ratio of 30:2 compressions to breaths when alone (or 15:2 with a second rescuer), and check the brachial pulse to ensure effective resuscitation efforts.

questions.text: A 42-year-old patient is being evaluated for their response to low oxygen levels. Identify the ion channel primarily dependent on oxygen levels which is involved in the function of peripheral chemoreceptors?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Potassium

 

  • Potassium ions (K⁺) play a critical role in the function of peripheral oxygen-sensing chemoreceptors, particularly in the carotid bodies.
  • Under hypoxic conditions, the activity of oxygen-sensitive potassium channels in these chemoreceptors is inhibited.
  • This inhibition leads to cell depolarization, causing an influx of calcium through voltage-gated calcium channels.
  • The increase in intracellular calcium triggers the release of neurotransmitters, which signal the respiratory centers in the brain to increase ventilation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Calcium: Although calcium influx is a subsequent step in the process, it is the inhibition of potassium channels that initiates the response to hypoxia in peripheral chemoreceptors.

 

Option B. Sodium: Sodium ions are involved in general cellular function and action potentials, but they are not the primary ions involved in oxygen sensing in peripheral chemoreceptors.

 

Option D. Chlorine: Chlorine ions (Cl⁻) do not play a direct role in the oxygen sensing mechanism of peripheral chemoreceptors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Potassium ions are crucial for the function of peripheral oxygen-sensing chemoreceptors, where their inhibition under hypoxic conditions leads to cell depolarization and subsequent respiratory responses.

questions.text: When evaluating the broader applicability of a clinical study's results to different populations and settings, which term best describes this aspect of research validity?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Generalization

 

  • External validity refers to the extent to which the findings of a study can be generalized beyond the specific conditions of the initial research.
  • This involves applying the study results to different populations, settings, or times and is crucial for the broader applicability of research conclusions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Replicability: Involves the ability to repeat a study under similar conditions and achieving similar results, which pertains to the reliability of the findings rather than their applicability.

 

Option C. Objectivity: Deals with the neutrality of the research, ensuring that the study is free from researcher bias, which is not directly related to how widely the findings can be applied.

 

Option D. Causality: Concerns whether the study can validly establish that one variable causes an effect on another, focusing more on internal validity than on generalization.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Internal validity is the extent to which a research study establishes a trustworthy cause-and-effect relationship
  • External validity is the extent to which you can generalize the findings of a study to other situations, people, settings and measures

questions.text: A patient presents with symptoms of irritability, dermatitis, and anemia. Urinalysis reveals elevated levels of xanthurenic acid. This finding indicates a deficiency in which vitamin?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Vitamin B6 deficiency

 

  • Xanthurenic acid in the urine is a biomarker for Vitamin B6 (pyridoxine) deficiency.
  • Vitamin B6 is a coenzyme involved in the metabolism of tryptophan to niacin.
  • In the absence of sufficient Vitamin B6, the metabolism of tryptophan is altered, leading to the accumulation of xanthurenic acid, which is then excreted in the urine.
  • This biochemical pathway disruption is a specific indicator of Vitamin B6 deficiency.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin B1 deficiency: This leads to conditions such as beriberi and Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome, which are characterized by neurological and cardiovascular symptoms, but not by increased urinary xanthurenic acid.

 

Option B. Vitamin B2 deficiency: Also known as riboflavin deficiency, it can cause ariboflavinosis, characterized by sore throat, redness and swelling of the lining of the mouth and throat, cracks or sores on the outsides of the lips (cheilosis) and at the corners of the mouth (angular stomatitis), and a moist, scaly skin (seborrheic dermatitis), but does not affect xanthurenic acid levels in urine.

 

Option D. Niacin deficiency: Niacin deficiency causes pellagra, which is characterized by dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia. However, it does not lead to elevated levels of xanthurenic acid in the urine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Elevated xanthurenic acid in the urine is a specific indicator of Vitamin B6 (pyridoxine) deficiency, which disrupts tryptophan metabolism.

choices.text: Fetal growth restriction

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman, G2P1, presents for her 14-week antenatal checkup. The obstetrician recommends a uterine artery Doppler ultrasound. What condition is this test primarily used to detect at this stage of pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Early-onset preeclampsia

 

  • A uterine artery Doppler ultrasound performed in early pregnancy is primarily used to assess the blood flow in the uterine arteries, which supply blood to the placenta.
  •  This test helps identify pregnancies at risk for early-onset preeclampsia.
  • Abnormal Doppler findings, such as increased resistance or notching in the uterine arteries, indicate poor placentation, which is a significant risk factor for developing early-onset preeclampsia.
  •  Early detection allows for closer monitoring and potential interventions to improve outcomes for both the mother and the fetus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fetal growth restriction (FGR): Although uterine artery Doppler can indicate risk for FGR due to poor placentation, its primary use in early pregnancy is for the detection of early-onset preeclampsia.

 

Option B. Placenta accreta: This condition involves abnormal attachment of the placenta to the uterine wall and is typically diagnosed through detailed ultrasound imaging in later stages of pregnancy. Uterine artery Doppler is not used for detecting placenta accreta.

 

Option D. Late-onset preeclampsia: While uterine artery Doppler can sometimes provide information related to the risk of preeclampsia, it is primarily useful for detecting early-onset preeclampsia. Late-onset preeclampsia, occurring after 34 weeks, is less frequently associated with abnormal Doppler findings early in pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A uterine artery Doppler ultrasound at 14 weeks of gestation is primarily used to detect the risk of developing early-onset preeclampsia by assessing blood flow in the uterine arteries.

questions.text: A 32-year-old Rh-negative woman had a normal delivery. Post-delivery, the test shown in the image was performed to assess for fetal-maternal hemorrhage. What is this test?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Kleihauer-Betke test

 

  • The Kleihauer-Betke test is used to quantify the extent of fetal-maternal hemorrhage by differentiating between fetal and maternal red blood cells based on their resistance to acid elution.
  •  In this test, a blood smear is treated with an acid solution that removes hemoglobin from adult red cells, leaving them as pale "ghost" cells, while fetal cells, which contain fetal hemoglobin, remain stained and appear bright pink.
  • This test helps in determining the appropriate dose of Rh immunoglobulin needed to prevent alloimmunization in Rh-negative women after delivery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Flow cytometry: This technique can quantify fetal cells in maternal blood by detecting cell surface markers, but it does not produce the characteristic staining pattern shown in the image.

 

Option B. Rosette test: The rosette test is a qualitative screening method used to detect the presence of fetal red blood cells in maternal blood, but it does not provide the detailed visualization seen in the image.

 

Option D. Peripheral smear: A peripheral smear is used to examine the morphology of blood cells to detect various hematological disorders, but it does not specifically differentiate fetal from maternal red blood cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Kleihauer-Betke test is used to quantify fetal-maternal hemorrhage by identifying fetal red blood cells that resist acid elution, aiding in the management of Rh-negative women post-delivery.

choices.text: Smear would help in establishing the diagnosis
Griseofulvin would help in resolution
Biopsy would be needed to establish the diagnosis

questions.text: A 36-year-old male presents with asymptomatic lesions on chest and back. His woods lamp examination is as given below showing yellow fluorescence. Pick the true statement regarding the condition:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Smear would help in establishing the diagnosis

 

  • The yellow fluorescence under Wood's lamp examination is characteristic of pityriasis versicolor, a superficial fungal infection caused by Malassezia species.
  • The condition presents with hypopigmented or hyperpigmented macules and patches that can fluoresce yellow under Wood's lamp.
  • Diagnosis is typically confirmed by performing a potassium hydroxide (KOH) smear, which reveals the characteristic "spaghetti and meatballs" appearance of the yeast and hyphae.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Autoimmune disease: Pityriasis versicolor is not an autoimmune disease; it is a fungal infection.

 

Option C. Griseofulvin would help in resolution: Griseofulvin is not effective against Malassezia species. Treatment typically involves topical or systemic antifungals such as ketoconazole, selenium sulfide, or terbinafine.

 

Option D. Biopsy would be needed to establish the diagnosis: A biopsy is not usually necessary for diagnosing tinea versicolor. A KOH smear is sufficient and less invasive.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pityriasis versicolor is diagnosed using a KOH smear, which shows the characteristic fungal elements.
  • Wood's lamp examination can aid in the diagnosis by showing yellow fluorescence of the affected areas.

questions.text: A patient present with poor wound healing, erythematous scaly pustular lesions around the mouth, and diarrhea. Which nutrient deficiency is most likely responsible for these symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Zinc

 

  • Zinc deficiency is known to cause a range of symptoms including poor wound healing, dermatitis particularly around orifices such as the mouth (perioral region), and gastrointestinal issues such as diarrhea.
  • Zinc plays a crucial role in maintaining skin integrity, immune function, and gastrointestinal health, which explains the diverse symptoms when deficient.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Selenium: Deficiency primarily affects the immune system and thyroid function but does not typically present with the symptoms described.

 

Option C. Iodine: Deficiency mainly causes goiter and thyroid dysfunction, not directly linked to wound healing or dermatological manifestations.

 

Option D. Copper: While copper deficiency can cause neutropenia and anemia, its deficiency symptoms do not typically include severe skin lesions and diarrhea.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Zinc deficiency is Acrodermatitis enteropathica (ADE), a disorder of zinc absorption or acquired, usually described in alcoholics:
    • Clinical triad of acral dermatitis, alopecia and diarrhea
    • Zinc deficiency may decrease rates of fibroplasia, epithelialization, and collagen synthesis and impaired wound healing

choices.text: Complete blood count
ESR by Wintrobe's method

questions.text: Which of the following tests should be performed using the vacutainer shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) TSH levels

 

  • The yellow-top vacutainer contains a serum separator tube (SST) with a clot activator and gel for serum separation.
  • This type of vacutainer is suitable for tests that require serum, such as TSH levels and other biochemical assays.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Complete blood count: A complete blood count (CBC) requires whole blood and is typically performed using a lavender-top vacutainer containing EDTA as an anticoagulant. The yellow-top vacutainer is not suitable for CBCs.

 

Option B. ESR by Wintrobe's method: The erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) by Wintrobe's method requires whole blood with an anticoagulant, typically collected in a black-top or lavender-top vacutainer with EDTA. The yellow-top vacutainer is not appropriate for this test.

 

Option D. Peripheral smear: A peripheral smear also requires whole blood, typically collected in a lavender-top vacutainer with EDTA. The yellow-top vacutainer is not suitable for preparing a peripheral smear.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The yellow-top vacutainer is used for serum separation and is suitable for tests that require serum, such as TSH levels.
  • It is not appropriate for tests requiring whole blood or plasma, such as a CBC, ESR, or peripheral smear.

questions.text: Based on the provided image, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Dermoid

 

  • Ocular dermoids are choristomas, containing tissue not normally found in the area.
  • They often appear as round, firm, and sometimes hair-bearing lesions on the surface of the eye or near the eyelids as given in the image.
  • Dermoids can vary in size and may cause astigmatism if they press against the cornea.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pterygium: This is a benign growth of conjunctival tissue that extends onto the cornea. It often presents as a wedge-shaped, fleshy growth and is usually found on the side closest to the nose. Pterygium is often associated with exposure to sunlight or wind, and its symptoms can include redness, irritation, or a feeling of something in the eye.

 

Option B. Pinguecula: Similar to a pterygium, a pinguecula is a benign, yellowish growth that occurs on the conjunctiva. It typically appears on the side of the eye nearest to the nose but does not grow onto the cornea. Pingueculae are also associated with long-term sun exposure and can cause irritation or dryness.

 

Option D. Dermolipoma: This is a type of choristoma, like dermoids, but it primarily consists of fatty tissue. Dermolipomas are usually located on the outer corner of the eye and appear as soft, yellowish masses. They are generally benign and asymptomatic, but their size and location can occasionally cause cosmetic or functional concerns.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Ocular dermoids, characterized by their distinct, tissue-composed appearance not normally present in that area, can cause visual disturbances such as astigmatism if they press against the cornea.
  • Identification and appropriate management are essential for maintaining ocular health and comfort.

questions.text: Which of the following hormones binds to nuclear receptors?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Thyroid hormones

 

Explanation:

 

Thyroid hormones bind to nuclear receptors, which are located within the cell nucleus. Upon binding to their receptors, thyroid hormones modulate gene expression by acting as transcription factors. This mechanism contrasts with hormones like glucocorticoids and mineralocorticoids that bind to cytoplasmic receptors, and hormones like ACTH and catecholamines that bind to cell surface G-protein coupled receptors (GPCRs).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glucocorticoids: Bind to cytoplasmic receptors.

 

Option C. ACTH: Binds to G-protein coupled receptors (GPCRs) on the cell surface.

 

Option D. Catecholamines - β receptors: Bind to cell surface receptors that activate the Gs protein-coupled receptor pathway.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thyroid hormones bind to nuclear receptors, influencing gene expression and regulating various metabolic processes. Understanding the receptor binding mechanisms of different hormones is crucial for comprehending their physiological actions and therapeutic targets.

choices.text: Aortic Sinus Bulging into Left Atrium
Aortic Sinus Bulging into Right Atrium

questions.text: A patient undergoes a cardiac imaging study, and the radiologist notes the presence of a prominent torus aorticus. What causes the appearance of the torus aorticus in the heart?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Aortic Sinus Bulging into Right Atrium

 

  • The torus aorticus is an anatomical prominence seen within the right atrium of the heart. It is caused by the bulging of the aortic sinus (a dilation at the base of the ascending aorta) into the right atrium.
  • This structure is a normal anatomical feature and can be visualized during imaging studies or during dissection of the heart.
  • The bulging of the aortic sinus into the right atrium forms this characteristic prominence.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Atrium Bulging into Aorta: The atrium does not bulge into the aorta; instead, the aortic sinus bulges into the right atrium. This description does not accurately describe the anatomical relationship that forms the torus aorticus.

 

Option B. Aortic Sinus Bulging into Left Atrium: The aortic sinus does not bulge into the left atrium. The torus aorticus is specifically related to the right atrium.

 

Option D. Aortic Wall Tear: An aortic wall tear, such as in the case of an aortic dissection, does not cause the torus aorticus. Aortic dissections are serious medical conditions but are unrelated to the normal anatomical prominence described by the torus aorticus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The torus aorticus is caused by the bulging of the aortic sinus into the right atrium, creating a normal anatomical prominence visible in cardiac imaging and dissection.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents with fatigue, jaundice, and abdominal distension. He has a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus. He reports consuming two standard drinks of alcohol once a week on Saturdays for the last 7 years. Liver function tests reveal AST of 56 and ALT of 75. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH)

 

Explanation:

 

The patient presents with features suggestive of chronic liver disease: fatigue, jaundice, and abdominal distension. While he reports alcohol consumption, the amount (two standard drinks per week) is below the threshold typically associated with significant liver damage in most individuals.
