In addition, his liver function tests show elevated AST and ALT, with an AST/ALT ratio <1. This pattern is more suggestive of NASH than alcoholic hepatitis, which often has an AST/ALT ratio >2. The presence of type 2 diabetes mellitus is a strong risk factor for NASH.

 

Educational objective:

 

Elevated AST and ALT, with an AST/ALT ratio <1 and chronic liver disease suggests of NASH

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient with mitochondrial dysfunction is being evaluated for persistent muscle weakness and fatigue. Laboratory tests show impaired ATP production. Which of the following processes is directly coupled to ATP generation during oxidative phosphorylation?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Proton translocation

 

  • During oxidative phosphorylation, ATP generation is directly coupled with proton translocation across the inner mitochondrial membrane.
  • This process creates a proton gradient, or proton motive force, which drives the synthesis of ATP via ATP synthase as protons flow back into the mitochondrial matrix.
  • This coupling of proton translocation to ATP generation is essential for efficient cellular respiration and energy production.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Electron flow through cytochromes: Although electron flow through cytochromes is critical for creating the proton gradient, it is the actual translocation of protons that directly couples with ATP synthesis, not the electron flow itself.

 

Option B. Reduction of NADH: In oxidative phosphorylation, NADH is oxidized, not reduced. The electrons released from NADH contribute to the electron transport chain, helping to create the proton gradient necessary for ATP production. Reduction of NADH does not directly couple with ATP generation.

 

Option D. Substrate level phosphorylation: This process generates ATP independently of oxidative phosphorylation, occurring during glycolysis and the TCA cycle. It does not involve the electron transport chain or proton translocation, thus is not part of the oxidative phosphorylation mechanism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Oxidative phosphorylation couples ATP generation with the translocation of protons across the inner mitochondrial membrane, creating a gradient that drives ATP synthesis.

questions.text: A patient with a documented exposure to rubella and no history of vaccination requires prophylactic treatment. What is the appropriate dosage of Rubella immunoglobulin to administer for effective exposure management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 20 mL

 

  • The appropriate dose for Rubella immunoglobulin following exposure to the rubella virus is 20 mL.
  • This dosage has been established to provide sufficient passive immunity to prevent or mitigate the effects of rubella, particularly in individuals who have not been vaccinated or are at high risk of severe illness.

 

Educational Objective:

 

IMMUNOGLOBULIN DOSAGES:

questions.text: During the perioperative management of a pediatric patient, understanding the fluid requirements is crucial to prevent complications such as dehydration or fluid overload. According to the 4-2-1 rule for fluid resuscitation, how much fluid per hour should a 15kg child receive?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 50 mL/hr

 

The 4-2-1 formula is a guideline for calculating maintenance fluid requirements in children. It is based on providing:

 

4 mL/kg/hr for the first 10 kg of body weight,

2 mL/kg/hr for the second 10 kg of body weight, and

1 mL/kg/hr for every kilogram of body weight thereafter.

For a 15 kg child, the calculation would be:

(4 mL/kg x 10 kg) + (2 mL/kg x 5 kg) = 40 mL + 10 mL = 50 mL/hr.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The 4-2-1 rule is an essential guideline for calculating hourly fluid requirements in pediatric patients, ensuring appropriate hydration status is maintained during the perioperative period.

choices.text: One basic health worker per 10,000 population
Responsibility of PHCs in malaria eradication

questions.text: Which of the following was NOT recommended by the Chadha Committee but by the Kartar Singh Committee instead?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) One PHC for 50,000 population

 

  • The Chadha Committee made several recommendations to strengthen primary healthcare, but the proposal to establish one Primary Health Centre (PHC) for every 50,000 populations was actually recommended by the Kartar Singh Committee.
  • The Chadha Committee focused on other organizational and structural enhancements for PHCs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. PHC at block level: This was indeed recommended by the Chadha Committee, aiming to align PHC services with local administrative structures to improve healthcare accessibility and coordination.

 

Option C. One basic health worker per 10,000 populations: Also a recommendation from the Chadha Committee, which aimed to improve the ratio of healthcare workers to population, ensuring better coverage and service delivery.

 

Option D. Responsibility of PHCs in malaria eradication: This was another focus of the Chadha Committee, integrating PHCs into broader public health campaigns, including malaria eradication, to leverage their community presence and capabilities.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following amino acids is primarily responsible for the absorption of ultraviolet light at a wavelength of 280 nm, allowing for the spectrophotometric analysis of protein solutions?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Tryptophan

 

  • Tryptophan is an aromatic amino acid that strongly absorbs ultraviolet light at a wavelength of 280 nm due to its indole ring structure.
  • This property is exploited in methods such as spectrophotometry to measure protein concentration in laboratory assays.
  • Phenylalanine and tyrosine, two other aromatic amino acids, also absorb UV light, but tryptophan has the strongest absorption and is typically the most significant contributor to a protein's UV absorbance profile.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Leucine: Leucine does not absorb UV light at 280 nm significantly because it lacks an aromatic ring structure.

 

Option B. Proline: Proline also does not significantly absorb UV light at 280 nm as it is not an aromatic amino acid.

 

Option C. Arginine: Arginine does not contribute to UV absorption at 280 nm significantly due to the lack of an aromatic ring structure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The properties of aromatic amino acids, specifically tryptophan, allows them to absorb ultraviolet light.
  • This absorption is utilized in laboratory techniques to analyze and quantify protein concentrations.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child is brought to the surgery clinic by his parents with a complaint of a bulge in his groin over the past few months. On examination, the bulge is reducible and shows expansile impulse on coughing. Which hormone is related to its development?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Calcitonin gene-related peptide (CGRP)

 

  • Calcitonin gene-related peptide (CGRP) has been implicated in the development of congenital inguinal hernias.
  •  It is one of the factors required for closure of processus vaginalis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Insulin-like growth factor (IGF):  IGF is involved in growth and development but is not specifically linked to hernia formation.

 

Option B. Thyroxine: Thyroxine is a thyroid hormone involved in metabolic regulation and is not associated with hernia development.

 

Option D. Collagenase: Collagenase is an enzyme that breaks down collagen. While it is related to tissue remodeling and repair, it is not directly implicated in hernia development.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Calcitonin gene-related peptide (CGRP) has a role in the development of hernias due to its influence on closure of processus vaginalis.

choices.text: CO2 retention due to opioid use

questions.text: A 32-year-old male involved in a road traffic accident presents with a pelvic fracture and head trauma. Following IV morphine administration for pain relief, he develops respiratory difficulty. What is the most likely cause of his respiratory symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) CO2 retention due to opioid use

 

  • After the administration of IV morphine, the most probable cause of the patient's respiratory difficulty is CO2 retention due to opioid use.
  • Morphine, an opioid analgesic, can suppress the respiratory center in the brainstem, leading to decreased respiratory drive.
  • This results in a reduced respiratory rate and tidal volume, subsequently causing hypercapnia (increased CO2 levels in the blood).
  • In a trauma patient, especially one with head injuries, careful monitoring of respiratory status is essential when administering opioids.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pelvic Fracture: While serious, pelvic fractures primarily cause pain and potential hemorrhagic shock but do not directly cause respiratory difficulties unless there are concomitant thoracic injuries.

 

Option C. Cerebral Edema: While cerebral edema could complicate head trauma and affect respiratory centers indirectly, the immediate timing post-opioid administration points more towards respiratory suppression by morphine.

 

Option D. Pulmonary Embolism: Although a consideration in trauma patients, especially with immobilization, there is no direct evidence in this scenario suggesting PE over the more immediate and likely effects of opioid-induced respiratory depression.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • Opioids like morphine can significantly depress respiratory function, which is critical to recognize and manage promptly, especially in patients with head trauma where monitoring for neurological changes is also vital.

questions.text: The detoxification of xenobiotics through a phase 1 hydroxylation reaction requires monooxygenase/cytochrome P-450 and which cofactor?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) NADPH

 

  • Phase 1 reactions in the detoxification of xenobiotics, particularly hydroxylation, involve the cytochrome P-450 enzyme system.
  • These reactions require NADPH as a cofactor to provide the necessary reducing equivalents.
  • NADPH supplies the electrons needed by cytochrome P-450 monooxygenase to activate oxygen and incorporate one atom of oxygen into the xenobiotic substrate while reducing the other oxygen atom to water.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. NADH: Although NADH is involved in various metabolic processes, it is not the primary cofactor used by cytochrome P-450 enzymes in phase 1 detoxification reactions.

 

Option B. FAD: FAD (Flavin adenine dinucleotide) acts as a cofactor in different oxidative reactions but is not directly involved in the hydroxylation reactions mediated by cytochrome P-450.

 

Option D. FADH2: Similar to FAD, FADH2 is involved in electron transport and other metabolic pathways but does not serve as the primary cofactor for cytochrome P-450 enzymes in phase 1 detoxification.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • NADPH is the essential cofactor required by cytochrome P-450 enzymes for phase 1 detoxification reactions, providing the reducing equivalents necessary for the hydroxylation of xenobiotics.

questions.text: A 50-year-old construction worker presents to the emergency department with severe abdominal pain, frequent vomiting, and watery diarrhea. During the physical examination, the medical officer notices that his stools emit a faint luminescent glow. The worker appears disoriented and weak. He mentions that he had been working at a site where chemical fertilizers were used heavily. Which substance exposure is most likely causing his symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Phosphorus

 

  • Acute phosphorus poisoning is characterized by luminescent stools, severe abdominal pain, vomiting, and diarrhea.
  • This distinctive symptom helps in differentiating phosphorus toxicity from other types of poisoning.
  • The stools also release mild fumes and this is called ‘smoky stool syndrome’.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mercury: Symptoms: Tremors, memory loss, gingivitis, and gastrointestinal distress.

 

Option B. Cadmium: Symptoms: Nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, and renal damage.

 

Option D. Calcium: Symptoms: Hypercalcemia, muscle weakness, confusion, and abdominal pain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Comparison of Poisoning Types:

questions.text: A concerned parent brings their 3-day-old infant to the clinic, who has developed a skin rash. The rash is shown in the image below. You do a microscopic examination of the lesions in the rash which reveals the presence of neutrophils. You reassure the mother of the rash's harmless and transient nature. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pustular melanosis

 

  • The presence of vesiculopustular lesions on the newborn, combined with neutrophils found on microscopic examination, indicates transient pustular melanosis.
  • This benign condition is more commonly seen in African-American neonates and presents at birth with vesiculopustular eruptions around the chin, neck, back, extremities, and palms or soles.
  • The pustular phase lasts for about 2-3 days, and the hyperpigmented macules that follow can persist for up to 3 months.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Mongolian spots: These are slate-blue, demarcated areas of pigmentation seen over the buttocks and back, also known as dermal melanocytosis. They do not present as pustular lesions.

 

Option C. Erythema toxicum: This condition presents as small white papules on an erythematous base, usually containing eosinophils, and can persist for about a week.

 

Option D. Cutis marmorata: This is a transient lacy reticular vascular pattern of the skin due to exaggerated physiologic vasomotor response to low environmental temperature and does not present as pustular lesions.

 

Educational Objective

 

  • Transient pustular melanosis is a benign condition in newborns characterized by vesiculopustular lesions that contain neutrophils.

choices.text: Immersion in water for more than 36 hours

questions.text: What is the cause of the condition given below?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Immersion in water for more than 36 hours

 

  • The above image shows washerwoman's feet/ washerwoman's skin. It is seen in a case of immersion in water (both antemortem as well as postmortem drowning).
  • It denotes skin maceration or swelling and wrinkling of the skin due to water absorption. Following changes are seen in washerwoman skin:
    • Wrinkling: After 3 hrs of immersion
    • Soddening (filled with water): After 12 hrs of immersion
    • Bleaching (whitening): After 36 hrs of immersion
    • Peeling: after 72 hrs of immersion
  • In the image, bleaching can be seen

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Diabetic neuropathy: Diabetic neuropathy typically presents with sensory deficits, pain, or ulcers but does not cause the skin changes seen in the image.

 

Option B. Hanging: Hanging does not cause the specific wrinkling and bleaching of the skin seen in the image.

 

Option D. Burns of foot: Burns would result in charring, blistering, and other thermal injuries, not the wrinkling and bleaching seen in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Washerwoman's feet (or skin) is characterized by swelling, wrinkling, and bleaching due to prolonged immersion in water, typically observed after more than 36 hours.

questions.text: In a rural village with 100 children under the age of five, a measles outbreak occurred after one confirmed case. The measles vaccine coverage in this population is 60%. Following this case, 26 of the children contracted measles. What is the secondary attack rate among the susceptible population?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 65%

 

  • To calculate the secondary attack rate, we first determine the number of susceptible children.
  • With a vaccination coverage of 60% in a population of 100 children, 40 children are unvaccinated and susceptible.
  • Of these, 26 developed measles following exposure.
  • The secondary attack rate is calculated as follows:

 

 

Interpretation: Two-thirds of those susceptible develop the disease from primary case within range of incubation period.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cases in epidemiology:

 

  • Primary case: First case of communicable disease introduced into the population unit being studied
  • Index case: First case that comes to the notice of the investigator (first case reported to the health system)
  • Secondary cases: Cases that develop from contact with the primary case
  • Secondary Attack Rate (SAR): Is no. of exposed persons developing the disease within range of incubation period, following exposure to the primary case.
